[[File:Electric cattle prod.jpg|thumb|250px|Electric cattle prod from the 1950s.]] A '''cattle prod''', also called a '''stock prod''', is a handheld device commonly used to make [[cattle]] or other [[livestock]] move by striking or poking them. An '''electric cattle prod''' is a stick with electrodes on the end which is used to make cattle move through a relatively high-voltage, low-current [[electric shock]]. The electric cattle prod is said to have been invented by Texas cattle baron [[Robert J. Kleberg (King Ranch)|Robert J. Kleberg, Jr.]]<ref name="Broyles">{{cite web |last = Broyles |first = William |title = The Last Empire |work = Texas Monthly |publisher = Emmis Publishing, L.P. |date = October 1980 |url = http://www.texasmonthly.com/topics/king-ranch |format = |doi = |accessdate = December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Hutton">{{cite book |last1 = Hutton |first1 = Paul Andrew |title = Western Heritage: A Selection of Wrangler Award-Winning Articles |publisher = University of Oklahoma Press |date = 2013 |location = |pages = 117 |language = |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LbgWVCk1YXsC&pg=PT117&dq=%22cattle+prod%22 |doi = |id = |isbn = 0806189738 }}</ref> of the [[King Ranch]] around 1930, although versions were sold as early as 1917.
== Terminology differences == [[File:Electric cattle prod 1917.png|250px|thumb|upright=1.3|An ad for an electric cattle prod in 1917 magazine]] Ranchers and farmers typically use the term "cattle prods" mainly to refer to simple non-electrified [[fiberglass]] or [[metal]] [[goad]]s used to physically encourage cattle into motion; the majority of people living outside of rural areas use the term 'cattle prod' exclusively for the electrified variant. Most ranchers and farmers refer to electric cattle prods as "hotshots"{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} (this is an example of a [[genericized trademark]]; one of the most prominent [[brand]]s of electric prod is Hot-Shot).<ref name="torture democracy">{{cite book |title= Torture and democracy|last= Rejali|first= Darius|authorlink=Darius Rejali |year= 2007|publisher= Princeton University Press|location= Princeton, New Jersey|isbn= 0-691-11422-6|page= 228|pages= |url= }}</ref>
In an electric cattle prod, which is the precursor to the modern day stun gun, dual surface [[electrodes]] produce a very high [[voltage]]/very low [[electric current|current]] [[electric arc]] between them, which, when pressed against conductive skin, produces a painful but superficial electric shock which stimulates the target to cease their current activity and move in the direction opposite the source of the pain. With higher current, the cattle prod is the equivalent of a stun gun and functions exactly the same way. Cattle prods are the precursor to direct contact [[electric stun gun]]s used against humans, and their basic operating principles are the same. The major differences are primarily in the matter of size and power: cattle prods tend to have a higher [[electric current]] and a longer handle than stun guns, which is helpful when dealing with very large, powerful animals.
== Regular prods == {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2008}} Regular cattle prods can actually be anything from a baton ([[goad]]) or piece of pipe properly wired, to a manufactured [[fiberglass]] rod with a rubber handle or even a rectangular-shaped device similar to today's stun guns, which also feature batons. Most prods use two metal tips, but some are rubberized for herding stubborn animals. A [[Wiffleball]] bat is also often used as an effective prod because the hollow plastic bat makes a sharp ringing sound when slapped against the skin.
Unlike hotshots, which produce high voltage and can be effective on humans, regular cattle prods used on animals are simply used to tap, strike, or poke an animal (usually on the flanks), depending on how stubborn the animal is. Sometimes, a prod can be used as a sort of "extended fence", allowing one to simply intimidate skittish animals away from open gates or downed fences without having to touch them.
== Electric prods == A hotshot is typically [[cylindrical]], and can carry an open [[electric current]] at the "shock end" when activated. The electric current at the shock end runs through two metal electrodes. Anything that touches the electric current receives a high-[[voltage]] low-[[ampere|current]] shock, not strong enough to kill a human or a large animal such as a cow or sheep from short-term exposure, but strong enough to cause significant pain.
The electric cattle prod is designed to inflict a painful shock to cattle, and thus "prod" them along; the pain stimulates movement. Some higher-voltage prods can interfere with [[radio]] and [[CB radio]] reception when activated.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}}
There are various designs of electric cattle prods. Their shape is often subject to guidelines of what can easily be used and handled. They range in length from six inches (usually of a more encased rectangular [[prism (geometry)|prism]] design like a [[Electroshock weapon|stun gun]]), to up to six feet. As the precursor of stun guns, cattle prods also have a wide range of voltage with enough current to operate in the same manner as a stun gun does against humans. A stun gun is nothing more than a beefed up cattle prod and both can be used on humans or animals by design. Whether it is called a cattle prod or a stun gun, both units are shaped for easy carry and function in the same manner against animals or humans. Most are simple designs powered by 9-volt or a combination of other types of batteries. Anything out of that range is usually too heavy and unwieldy for practical use. Another typical design is a box containing a large battery (or battery pack) at the handle end and wires embedded in a fibreglass rod, ending with two electrodes in a rubber tip. This design is well-suited for use as a regular cattle prod.
The use of electric cattle prods has been debated by many people.<ref>Book: ''The Welfare of Cattle'', By Jeffrey Rushen, Anne Maria De Passille, Marina A. G. von Keyserlingk, Daniel M. Weary, Contributor Jeffrey Rushen, Anne Maria De Passille, Marina A. G. von Keyserlingk, Published by Springer, 2007, {{ISBN|1-4020-6557-4}} / {{ISBN|978-1-4020-6557-6}}, 310 pages</ref><ref>Editorial: A cattle prod for USDA, Saturday, February 23, 2008 - Slaughter plant workers videotaped shocking sick cattle with prods to keep them on their feet before slaughter [http://www.sacbee.com/110/story/732673.html Sacbee.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724070518/http://www.sacbee.com/110/story/732673.html |date=2008-07-24 }}</ref> Organizations such as [[PETA]] contend that the use of cattle prods is as much mentally harmful as it is physically.<ref>Link to PETA website GoVeg.com, ''[http://www.goveg.com/factoryFarming_cows.asp Cruelty to Animals: Cows]''</ref> Most farmers contend that the short shock is minutely felt, and soon forgotten.<ref>Friends of Rodeo Fact Sheet, discussing use of cattle prods. ''The electric cattle prod is a humane device when properly used.'' [http://www.friendsofrodeo.com/help3.html Friendsofrodeo.com]</ref>
=== Usage on people, policing, torture and treatment === [[File:2004-7-6-gao rongrong3.jpg|thumb|[[Gao Rongrong]], a [[Falun Gong]] practitioner from China, was reported tortured to death in custody in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amnesty International Annual Report 2006|url=https://www.amnesty.de/umleitung/2006/deu03/031?lang=de%26mimetype%3dtext%2fhtml|website=Amnesty International|accessdate=29 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140725121554/https://www.amnesty.de/umleitung/2006/deu03/031?lang=de%26mimetype%3dtext%2fhtml|archivedate=2014-07-25|language=German|date=March 2006|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>]] Cattle prods today are designed with a high range of voltages and currents. If more powerful prods are applied continuously to the skin, the current eventually causes heating, [[searing]], burning, and scarring of skin at the contact point. Electric prods have found favour with torturers.<ref name="NewInternationist2000">{{cite news |last1=Crowley |first1=Michael |title=Trading In Shock |url=https://newint.org/features/2000/09/05/trading |accessdate=29 November 2017 |work=New Internationalist |issue=327 |date=5 September 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022143826/https://newint.org/features/2000/09/05/trading/ |archivedate=2016-10-22 |quote=Electroshock weapons have become a favoured tool of many of the world's torturers. The 'torture trail' has often begun with companies in Europe and the US. |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
Prior to the development of [[stun baton]]s and the [[taser]], electric cattle prods were also used on people in varying degrees. Their first common usage on people occurred during the [[Civil Rights Movement]] of the 1960s; prods were first adopted by police officers in [[Alabama]] to use on protesters and agencies elsewhere followed; Hotshot later developed an electric police baton.<ref name="torture democracy"/>
The [[picana]] is an electric prod based originally on the cattle prod but designed specifically for human torture. It works at very high voltage and low current so as to maximize pain and minimize the physical marks left on the victim. Among its advantages over other torture devices is that it is portable, easy to use, and allows the torturer to localize the electric shocks to the most sensitive places on the body, where they cause intense pain that can be repeated many times.
Electric prods have been used for the control of adverse self-injuring behavior in mentally handicapped people. This use is regarded by some advocates to be more effective than drugs since the experience of a shock is very short and temporary while using a drug may have long-lasting sedative effects.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kersey |first1=Brian |title=Autistic man's care renews shocking debate |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/17616714/ |accessdate=29 November 2017 |agency=Associated Press |date=March 14, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306120741/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/17616714/ |archivedate=2016-03-06 |quote=Bradley Bernstein’s parents say an electric cattle prod is the only thing that stops him from banging his head and violently punching his eyes, nearly blinding himself. |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On August 14, 2013 in [[Lakewood Township, New Jersey]], [[Mendel Epstein]] told two undercover [[FBI]] agents that he used a cattle prod to coerce [[Jewish]] husbands to grant [[Get (divorce document)|religious divorces]] to their wives, leading the press to nickname him "The Prodfather". He was convicted of conspiring to commit [[kidnapping]], and sentenced to 10 years in prison.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mullen|first1=Shannon|title=10-year sentence for Lakewood 'Prodfather' rabbi|url=http://www.app.com/story/news/local/jackson-lakewood/lakewood/2015/12/15/lakewood-rabbi-epstein-divorce-gets/77351110/|work=USA Today|date=December 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Blau|first1=Reuven|title=N.J. jury finds Orthodox rabbi guilty of kidnap-divorce plot|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/orthodox-rabbi-guilty-kidnapping-beating-jewish-husbands-article-1.2193597|date=April 22, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825145824/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/orthodox-rabbi-guilty-kidnapping-beating-jewish-husbands-article-1.2193597|archivedate=2017-08-25|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Albert|first1=Samaha|title=Bad Rabbi: Tales of Extortion and Torture Depict a Divorce Broker’s Brutal Grip on the Orthodox Community|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2013/12/04/bad-rabbi-tales-of-extortion-and-torture-depict-a-divorce-brokers-brutal-grip-on-the-orthodox-community/|work=Village Voice|date=December 4, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011182910/https://www.villagevoice.com/2013/12/04/bad-rabbi-tales-of-extortion-and-torture-depict-a-divorce-brokers-brutal-grip-on-the-orthodox-community/|archivedate=2017-10-11|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> This aspect of the cattle prod has been touted as an advantage for its use in [[torture]].<ref>Marsh, Julia and Fears, Danika (April 6, 2016) [https://nypost.com/2016/04/06/take-an-electric-cattle-prod-footage-shows-rabbi-discussing-husband-torture/ "Rabbi Used Electric Cattle Prod to Force Husbands into Religious Divorces"], ''New York Post''</ref>
== Alternatives == {{main|Animal welfare}} Cattle can be difficult to move and direct for a variety of reasons. Prods can be useful for moving stubborn or aggressive animals,<ref name="grandin20">{{cite book |title= Animals in Translation|last= Grandin|first= Temple|authorlink= Temple Grandin|author2=Johnson, Catherine|year= 2005|publisher= Scribner|location= New York, New York|isbn= 0-7432-4769-8|page= 20|pages= |url= }}</ref> but often cattle will not move forward when they are fearful of something they see, hear, or smell. Removal of these distractions or hiding them, such as with solid wall partitions, can greatly reduce animal handling problems,<ref>Link to Temple Grandin's website page, discussing common distractions that prevent animal movement through chutes and gates, with pictures of the distractions from the animal's viewpoint, [http://www.grandin.com/behaviour/principles/distraction.html grandin.com]</ref> however, cattle handlers cannot completely overcome the animal's decision not to move forward.
By studying the psychology of the animals and redesigning the working environment it is possible to handle the animals without the need for brute force and causing pain and suffering to the animal in many, but not all, cases. Significant work in this regard has been done by [[Colorado State University]] professor [[Temple Grandin]] to study how cattle perceive the environment around them and to design better livestock [[slaughterhouse]] handling systems that do not induce fear into the animal.<ref>Grandin, T. "Best Practices for Animal Handling and Stunning", ''Meat & Poultry'', April 2000, pg. 76, [http://www.grandin.com/humane/best.practices.handle.stun.html grandin.com]</ref>
== In popular culture ==
In the [[Martin Scorsese]] film ''[[Casino]]'', a cheating gambler is shocked with a cattle prod by a security guard, which is passed off as a heart attack. As an example of "cheater's justice," he is threatened with a circular saw and has his fingers broken with a hammer.
In ''[[Fargo (TV series)|Fargo]]'', a television crime series based on [[Fargo (film)|the film of the same name]], a cattle prod is used on numerous occasions as a weapon against humans in [[Fargo (season 2)|season 2]].<ref name=Mumford>{{cite web|last1=Mumford|first1=Trac|title='Fargo' recap: You have no idea what's coming|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2015/11/03/fargo-episode-four-recap|website=mprnews.com|publisher=MPR News|accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=Moses>{{cite web|last1=Moses|first1=Zane|title='Fargo' recap: Of cattle prods and men|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/bthesite/tv-lust/bal-fargo-recap-of-cattle-prods-and-men-20151117-story.html|website=baltimoresun.com|publisher=Baltimore Sun|accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref>
In ''[[Pretty Little Liars]]'', a popular television series, a cattle prod was used to torture one of the leading characters [[Hanna Marin]]. In [[Ridley Scott]]'s 1979 horror film ''[[Alien (film)|Alien]]'', [[Ellen Ripley]] and her crew attempt to capture an escaped [[Alien (creature in Alien franchise)|Xenomorph]] with the help of a cattle prod.
In [[Margaret Atwood]]'s 1985 novel ''[[The Handmaid's Tale]]'' and the 2017 [[Hulu]] [[The Handmaid's Tale (TV series)|TV series adaptation]], cattle prods are used by the Aunts to control the Handmaids, a class of fertile women who serve as surrogates for the ruling Commanders.
In ''[[Bottom (TV series)|Bottom]]'', a British television sitcom, in Season 3 Episode 2 (''[[Terror (Bottom)|Terror]]''), a homemade cattle prod device is used to convince people to hand over money during [[Halloween]].
Cattle prods feature as usable weapons in the video games [[Fallout]], [[Fallout 2]] and [[Fallout: New Vegas]], the latter themed around agricultural society in the American Southwest
In the 2017 film ''[[The Shape of Water]]'', a cattle prod features prominently. It is the weapon of choice used by the primary antagonist, Col. Strickland, who carries it with him constantly. The head of a secret government program that captures and studies the Amphibian Man, Strickland uses the cattle prod to torture both him and a Soviet spy who infiltrates the program. Strickland introduces the cattle prod to the protagonists, saying "That lovely dingus right there is an Alabama howdy-do. Molded grip handle, low-current high-voltage electric shock cattle prod".

{{Infobox play | name = '''Clybourne Park''' | image = Clybourne Park.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | writer = [[Bruce Norris (playwright)|Bruce Norris]] | premiere = {{Start date|2010|02|01}} | place = [[Playwrights Horizons]]
[[New York City]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = Response to ''[[A Raisin in the Sun]]'' | genre = Drama}} '''''Clybourne Park''''' is a 2010 play by [[Bruce Norris (playwright)|Bruce Norris]] written as a spin-off to [[Lorraine Hansberry]]'s play ''[[A Raisin in the Sun]]'' (1959). It portrays fictional events set before and after the Hansberry play, and is loosely based on historical events that took place in the city of Chicago. It premiered in February 2010 at [[Playwrights Horizons]] in New York.{{cite news|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/136395-Clybourne-Park-With-Wood-Parisse-Shamos-and-More-Begins-NYC-World-Premiere|title=Clybourne Park, With Wood, Parisse, Shamos and More, Begins NYC World Premiere|work=[[Playbill]]|accessdate=2011-04-19}} The play received its UK premiere at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] in [[London]] in a production directed by [[Dominic Cooke]]. The play received its Chicago premiere at [[Steppenwolf Theatre Company]] in a production directed by Steppenwolf ensemble member [[Amy Morton]].Thompson, Zac. [http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/clybourne-park-at-steppenwolf-theatre-company/Content?oid=4668963 “Clybourne Park gets its Chicago premiere”], ''Chicago Reader'', September 22, 2011; retrieved September 3, 2013. As described by ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the play "applies a modern twist to the issues of race and housing and aspirations for a better life."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/29/AR2010012900274.html|title=Peter Marks's theater picks for the spring|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=2010-01-29|accessdate=2011-04-19}} ''Clybourne Park'' was awarded the 2011 [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] and the 2012 [[Tony Award for Best Play]]. ==Plot== ===Act I: 1959=== Grieving parents Bev and Russ are planning to sell their home in the white middle-class Chicago neighborhood of Clybourne Park. They receive a visit from their local clergyman, Jim, as well as their neighbor Karl and his deaf, pregnant wife Betsy. Karl informs them that the family buying their house is black, and pleads with Russ to back out of the deal, for fear that falling area property values will drive the Lindners' neighbors away and isolate them if black residents move in. It becomes apparent that the black family moving in are the Youngers, the protagonists of ''[[A Raisin in the Sun]]'', and the neighbor is Karl Lindner, the minor character from that play who attempted to bribe the Youngers into abandoning their plans to move into the neighborhood. The action is taking place approximately an hour following Karl Lindner's departure from the Youngers' Hamilton Park residence, where they have rejected his bribery attempt. As arguments ensue about the potential problems of integrating the neighborhood, both couples awkwardly call on Russ and Bev's black housekeeper and her husband, Francine and Albert, to express their opposing views. Russ finally snaps and throws everyone out of the house, saying he no longer cares about his neighbors after their community's shunning his son Kenneth when he returned home from the Korean War, which contributed to Kenneth's suicide, which occurred inside the house. ===Act II: 2009=== Set in the same home as Act I, the same actors reappear playing different characters. In the intervening fifty years, Clybourne Park has become an all-black neighborhood, which is now [[gentrification|gentrifying]]. A white couple, Steve and Lindsay (played by the same actors who played Karl and Betsy in Act I), are seeking to buy, raze and rebuild the house at a larger scale, and are being forced to negotiate local housing regulations with a black couple, Kevin and Lena (played by the same actors as Francine and Albert), who represent the housing board. Lena is related to the Younger family (and named after matriarch Lena Younger), and is unwilling to have the house torn down. Steve and Lindsay's lawyer, Kathy (played by Bev) is revealed to be the daughter of Karl and his deaf wife, Betsy, and mentions that her family moved out of the neighborhood around the time of her birth. A cordial discussion of housing codes soon degenerates into one of racial issues, instigated by a concerned Steve, who feels that the mask of "political correctness" is allowing for a more subtle kind of prejudice against them. The alternating disgust and dismissal that follows reveals resentments from both parties, and several awkward comments lead to Steve being goaded into telling a racist, homophobic joke that offends both Kevin and the other lawyer, Tom (played by Jim), who is gay. The discussion is interrupted several times by Dan (played by Russ), a workman who has found Kenneth's army trunk buried in the back yard. As fighting erupts and the two couples turn on each other and themselves, Dan opens the trunk and finds Kenneth's suicide note. In a short coda, we see Bev back in 1957, catching her son awake late at night, dressed in his army uniform. He claims to be dressing for a job interview, though it is clear that he is in the act of writing his suicide note. Leaving him to tend to the house, Bev observes that "I really believe things are about to change for the better." ===Historical context=== Hansberry's parents bought a house in the white neighborhood of [[Washington Park, Chicago (neighborhood)|Washington Park]], an action that resulted in a legal case (''[[Hansberry v. Lee]]'', 311 U.S. 32 [1940]).Brantley, Ben, "Good Defenses Make Good Neighbors", ''The New York Times'', February 22, 2010. The Hansberry family home, a red brick three-floor at 6140 S. Rhodes, which they bought in 1937, is up for landmark status before the Chicago City Council's Committee on Historical Landmarks Preservation.{{cite news|author=Ihejirika, Maudlyne|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/2031043,CST-NWS-raisin05.article|title='Raisin in the Sun' home for landmark?|work=Chicago Sun-Times|date=February 5, 2010|accessdate=May 12, 2012}} ==Productions== The play premiered [[Off-Broadway]] at [[Playwrights Horizons]] on February 21, 2010, before closing on March 21, 2010. Directed by [[Pam MacKinnon]], the cast featured [[Frank Wood (actor)|Frank Wood]], [[Annie Parisse]], [[Jeremy Shamos]], Crystal A. Dickinson, Brendan Griffin, [[Damon Gupton]], and [[Christina Kirk]], The play premiered in the UK in August 2010 at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] in London directed by [[Dominic Cooke]], artistic director of the theatre, and starring [[Sophie Thompson]], [[Martin Freeman]], Lorna Brown, [[Sarah Goldberg]], Michael Goldsmith, [[Lucian Msamati]], [[Sam Spruell]] and [[Steffan Rhodri]].{{cite web|url=http://theculturalexpose.tumblr.com/post/3028810748/something-you-should-see-clybourne-park-wyndhams|title=The Cultural Exposé - A site for hip + arty urban adventurers|work=[[Tumblr]]|accessdate=April 19, 2011}} It transferred to [[Wyndham's Theatre]] in the [[West End theatre|West End]] with most of the original cast, with the exceptions of [[Martin Freeman]], who was replaced by [[Stephen Campbell Moore]]; and [[Steffan Rhodri]], who was replaced by [[Stuart McQuarrie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.clybournepark.co.uk|title=Clybourne Park in the West End|accessdate=April 19, 2011}} Even before the play premiered on Broadway, it had several notable productions in regional theatres: The [[Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company]] (Washington D.C.) staged it in March, 2010, with artistic director Howard Shalwitz directing.https://web.archive.org/web/20100327031711/http://www.woollymammoth.net:80/performances/show_clybourne_park.phphttps://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/03/24/AR2010032402981.html The Caldwell Theatre Company (Boca Raton, Florida) staged it in January 2011, with Clive Cholerton directing and starring Gregg Weiner, Karen Stephens, Brian D. Coats, Kenneth Kay, Patti Gardner, Cliff Burgess, and Margery Lowe. The play's Chicago premiere took place in September 2011 at [[Steppenwolf Theatre Company]],[http://www.steppenwolf.org/Plays-Events/productions/index.aspx?id=527 ''Clybourne Park''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621205909/http://www.steppenwolf.org/Plays-Events/productions/index.aspx?id=527 |date=2013-06-21 }} Steppenwolf Theatre Company directed by Steppenwolf ensemble member [[Amy Morton]] and featuring ensemble member James Vincent Meredith along with Karen Aldridge, Cliff Chamberlain, Stephanie Childers, Kirsten Fitzgerald, John Judd, and Brendan Marshall-Rashid; the production closed in November 2011.Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/steppenwolf-season-to-feature-john-mahoney-william-petersen-tracy-letts-pre-176620/ "Steppenwolf Season to Feature John Mahoney, William Petersen, Tracy Letts, Premiere of 'The March'"] Playbill, March 2, 2011Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/amy-morton-will-direct-steppenwolfs-clybourne-park-casting-announced-180192# "Amy Morton Will Direct Steppenwolf's 'Clybourne Park'; Casting Announced"] Playbill, June 17, 2011Zacher, Scotty. [http://chicagotheaterbeat.com/2011/09/21/review-clybourne-park-steppenwolf-theatre/ "Review. 'Clybourne Park' (Steppenwolf Theatre"] chicagotheaterbeat.com, September 21, 2011 In October/November 2011, the play was in residence with the [[Trinity Repertory Company]] in [[Providence, Rhode Island]], with Brian Mertes directing and starring Mauro Hantman, Rachael Warren, Mia Ellis, Anne Scurria, Timothy Crowe, Tommy Dickie, and Joe Wilson Jr.Hetrick, Adam.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/155664-Clybourne-Park-Opens-at-Trinity-Repertory-Company-Oct-19 "'Clybourne Park' Opens at Trinity Repertory Company Oct. 19"], playbill.com, October 19, 2011. From January to March 2012, the play ran at [[Arden Theatre Company (Philadelphia)|Arden Theatre Company]] in Old City, Philadelphia, directed by Ed Sobel and starring David Ingram, Julia Gibson, Erika Rose, Steve Pacek, Josh Tower, Ian Merrill Peakes, and Maggie Lakis. ''The Philadelphia Inquirer'' claimed, "A remarkably skillful cast directed by Edward Sobel creates characters that flirt with stereotypes, but become real and believable...This is a bitter satire that makes us laugh while it indicts us."[http://articles.philly.com/2012-02-03/news/31021696_1_youngers-clybourne-park-racist-attitudes Toby Zinman, "'Clybourne Park': Guilt and hypocrisy in a racially changing neighborhood"], ''The Philadelphia Inquirer'', February 3, 2012. The play opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Walter Kerr Theatre]] on April 19, 2012 (in previews starting March 26, 2012) for a 16-week limited engagement. The Off-Broadway cast reprised their roles.{{cite news|author=Kenneth Jones|title='Clybourne Park', the Pulitzer Winner About Race and Real Estate, Makes Broadway Debut|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/161063-Clybourne-Park-the-Pulitzer-Winner-About-Race-and-Real-Estate-Makes-Broadway-Debut|work=Playbill|date=March 26, 2012|accessdate=May 2, 2012}}{{cite news|author=Kenneth Jones|title='Clybourne Park', the Funny-Tragic Pulitzer Winner About Race and Real Estate, Opens on Broadway|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/165053-Clybourne-Park-the-Funny-Tragic-Pulitzer-Winner-About-Race-and-Real-Estate-Opens-on-Broadway|work=Playbill|date=April 19, 2012|accessdate=May 12, 2012}} The play was nominated for several [[Tony Awards]], and won the one for Best Play.{{cite web|last=Gans|first=Andrew|title=Broadway's Big Night! Neil Patrick Harris Hosts 66th Annual Tony Awards June 10|work=Playbill|date=2012-06-10|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/166878-Broadways-Big-Night-Neil-Patrick-Harris-Hosts-66th-Annual-Tony-Awards-June-10|accessdate=2012-06-10}} In 2013, the play was staged at the [[Guthrie Theater]] (May to June 2013),[http://www.guthrietheater.org/sites/default/files/playguide_Clybourne_Park.pdf "Play Guide, ''Clybourne Park'"] guthrietheater.org, accessed November 8, 2015 in rotating repertory with ''A Raisin in the Sun'' at the [[Dallas Theater Center]],[http://www.dallastheatercenter.org/show_details.php?sid=74 Dallas Theater Center] and in rotating repertory with [[Kwame Kwei-Armah]]'s ''Beneatha's Place'' at [[Center Stage (theater)|Center Stage]] in Baltimore.[http://www.centerstage.org/2012-13Season/TheRaisinCycle.aspx Center Stage: The Raisin Cycle], centerstage.org; accessed September 6, 2015. The play had several productions in 2014: in January at the [[Grand Rapids Civic Theatre & School of Theatre Arts|Grand Rapids Civic Theatre]],[http://grctclybourne2014.blogspot.com ''Clybourne Park'' at Grand Rapids Civic Theatre], grctclybourne2014.blogspot.com; accessed September 6, 2015. in February 2014, at the Wichita Center for the Arts in Wichita, Kansas,[http://www.wcfta.com/Theatre.html WCFTA Theatre] and in September as the season opener for the [[Hippodrome State Theatre]] in [[Gainesville, Florida]].[http://thehipp.org/mainstage/current-shows Hippodrome Theatre Mainstage: Current Shows] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140807103816/http://thehipp.org/mainstage/current-shows/ |date=2014-08-07 }}; accessed September 5, 2014. Also, the play's Australian premiere took place in March at the [[Ensemble Theatre]] in Sydney; the run was scheduled for five weeks, but sold out before opening night and was subsequently extended at another location.[http://ensemble.com.au/whats-on/play/clybourne-park "What's On"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320010426/http://ensemble.com.au/whats-on/play/clybourne-park/ |date=2014-03-20 }}, ensemble.com.au; accessed September 6, 2015. ==Awards and nominations== ; Awards * 2011 [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Play]]{{cite news| author=Ray Bennett |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/olivier-awards-2011-legally-blonde-167171|title=Olivier Awards 2011: 'Legally Blonde', Stephen Sondheim Dominate|date=March 13, 2011|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=April 19, 2011}} * 2011 [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]]{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/19/business/media/19PULITZERLIST-ARTS.html|title=2011 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music|date=April 19, 2011|work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 19, 2011}} * 2012 [[Theatre World Award]] – Crystal A. Dickinson * 2012 [[Tony Award for Best Play]] ; Nominations * 2010 London Critics Circle for Best New Play{{cite news|author=Kenneth Jones|title=Clybourne Park, Matilda and Suchet Honored in London's Critics' Circle Theatre Awards|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/146945-Clybourne-Park-Matilda-and-Suchet-Honored-in-Londons-Critics-Circle-Theatre-Awards|work=Playbill|date=January 25, 2011|accessdate=May 12, 2012}} * 2010 Evening Standard Theatre Award for Best Play{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/8168356/Evening-Standard-Theatre-Awards-a-year-to-be-proud-of.html|newspaper=The Telegraph|first=Charles|last=Spencer|title=Evening Standard Theatre Awards: a year to be proud of|date=November 29, 2010|accessdate=May 12, 2012}} * 2011 Chicago [[Jeff Award]] for Best Play (Large) * 2011 [[South Bank Sky Arts Award]] for Best Play{{cite web|title=South Bank Sky Arts Awards: The Winners|url=http://www.skyarts.co.uk/skyarts/south-bank-sky-arts-awards-the-winners|publisher=Sky '''Early music festivals''' is a generic term for musical festivals focused on music before [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], or including [[historically informed performance]] of later works. The increase in the number of [[music festival]]s specializing in [[early music]] is a reflection of the [[early music revival]] of the 1970s and 1980s. Many larger festivals such as that an [[Aix-en-Provence Festival]] also include early music sections, as do, inevitably, festivals of sacred music; such as the Festival de Música Sacra do Baixo Alentejo, in [[Portugal]]. Although most early music festivals are centered on commercial performance, many include also workshops. This articles includes an '''incomplete list of early music festivals''', which may overlap with topics such as [[Bach festival#List of Bach festivals|list of Bach festivals]], [[list of maritime music festivals]], [[list of opera festivals]], and in some cases [[list of folk festivals]].
==List of festivals by country== {{See also|Category:Early music festivals}} Note this list includes festivals that are annual unless otherwise listed. Festivals which were notable, producing radio-broadcasts and recordings, but now defunct, are listed with an indent at the end of each country listing; for example Gottorfer Barockmusiktage, Germany. {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} The '''International Edible Book Festival''' is an annual event usually held on or around April 1, which is also known as '''Edible Book Day'''.<ref name="week">{{cite news |url = http://week.manoramaonline.com/cgi-bin/MMOnline.dll/portal/ep/theWeekContent.do?BV_ID=@@@&contentType=EDITORIAL&sectionName=TheWeek%20Lifestyle&programId=1073755413&contentId=6895557 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714032142/http://week.manoramaonline.com/cgi-bin/MMOnline.dll/portal/ep/theWeekContent.do?BV_ID=%40%40%40&contentType=EDITORIAL&sectionName=TheWeek%20Lifestyle&programId=1073755413&contentId=6895557 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = July 14, 2011 |title = Write Bite |date = March 21, 2010 |work = [[The Week]] |publisher = Malayala Manorama Publications |location = Kochi, Kerala |access-date = March 18, 2010 |df = }}</ref> The global event has been celebrated since 2000 in various parts of the world, where "edible books" are created, displayed, and small events are held. The creations are photographed and then consumed.<ref name="week"/> Regular contributors to the site are groups from Australia, Brazil, India, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Mexico, Morocco, The Netherlands, Russia, and Hong Kong. The event was initiated by Judith A. Hoffberg and Béatrice Coron in 2000.<ref name="week"/>
[[Image:Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin.jpg|thumb|Title page of "Physiologie du Goût" ("Physiology of Taste") by French gastronome [[Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin]] (1755–1826) with a portrait of the author. 1848 edition.]] The official website <nowiki>Books2Eat.com</nowiki> says that the International Edible Book Festival is held to commemorate "the birthday of French gastronome [[Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin]] (1755–1826), noted for his book ''Physiologie du goût'', a witty meditation on food", though [[April Fools' Day]] is also related as "the perfect day to eat your words and play with them as the 'books' are consumed on the day of the event".<ref name="books2eat">{{cite web |url = http://www.books2eat.com |title = International Edible Book Festival |publisher = Diffusion [[Adage]] |access-date = April 1, 2016 }}</ref> (cf. ''[[The Phantom Tollbooth]]'', as regards eating one's words.)
==Rules== The participation rules per a related site are:<ref name="books2eat"/> * The event must be held on April 1 or around it * "All edible books must be 'bookish' through the integration of text, literary inspiration or, quite simply, the form." * "Organizations or individual participants must register with the festival’s organization ... and see to it that the event is immortalized on the international festival website ( http://www.books2eat.beatricecoron.com/ )." It should be noted that this site is collecting photographs for publication in a book.
==Celebrations== [[File:Chatham University Edible Book Festival Hunger Games.jpg|thumb|2012 [[Chatham University]] Edible Book Festival, exhibit dedicated to ''[[The Hunger Games]]'']]
In 2005, the festival was a joint initiative of forum book art and the Museum of Work, [[Hamburg]], where pastry chefs made edible books. The "book art" was displayed, photographed, and then eaten.<ref>{{cite book |first = Heinz Stefan |last = Bartkowiak |chapter = The Sixth International Book Festival: 2005 |title = Kompendium zeitgenössischer Handpressendrucke, Malerbücher, Künstlerbücher, Einblattdrucke, Mappenwerke und Buchobjekte |trans-title = Compendium of Contemporary Fine Prints, Artists' Books, Broadsides, Portfolios and Book Objects |language = German, English |location = Hamburg |publisher = Bartkowiaks Forum Book Art |year = 2005 |chapter-url = https://books.google.com/?id=VFa4ctd1ReUC&pg=PA25 |page = 25 |isbn = 9783935462044 }}</ref> In 2005, the event was celebrated in [[Los Angeles]], too, at the Los Angeles Book Arts Center as the ''Annual International Edible Book High/Low Tea'' on April 2, where artists were encouraged to create and consume tomes.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Q18EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA156 |title = 6th Annual International Edible Book High/Low Tea |date = Apr 2005 |work = Los Angeles Magazine |page = 156 |access-date = March 18, 2010 }}</ref> A 2006 [[Indianapolis Monthly]] described the [[Indianapolis]] festival as a "quirky event" held on April Fools' Day, "celebrating both food and literature." Participants created foods resembling literary titles.<ref>{{cite news |title = International Edible Book Festival |date = Apr 2006 |work = [[Indianapolis Monthly]] |pages = 66 <!--|access-date = March 18, 2010--> }}</ref>
Loganberry Books in [[Shaker Heights, Ohio|Shaker Heights]], Ohio has held an [[Eating|edible]] books festival every April since 2004<ref>{{cite news |first = Karen R. |last = Long |url = http://www.cleveland.com/books/index.ssf/2010/03/edible_books_robert_sapolsky_a.html |title = Edible Books, Robert Sapolsky and Mentor's Laurie Abraham lead the literary week |work = Cleveland Plain Dealer |date = March 31, 2010 |access-date = April 11, 2013| }} Also {{cite news |url = http://www.cleveland.com/parents/index.ssf/2010/03/read_your_book_and_eat_it_too.html |title = Read your book ... and eat it, too, at Loganberry's Edible Books Festival |work = Cleveland Plain Dealer |date = March 29, 2010 |access-date = April 11, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://clevelandpoetics.blogspot.com/2013/04/books-so-good-you-can-eat-them-really.html |title = Books So Good You can Eat them. Really |work = Clevelandpoetics |date = April 4, 2013 |access-date = April 11, 2013 }}</ref> In 2013, awards were given for Most Literary, Most Appetizing, Most Book-like, and Most Creative.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.loganberrybooks.com/edible-books.html |publisher = Loganberry Books |title = Edible Books Festival |access-date = April 11, 2013 }}</ref>
A [[University of Florida]] library holds the event as the '''Edible Book Contest''' in April, in connection with [[National Library Week]]. There are two rules for the contest: Entries should be edible, and they must somehow relate to a book. Besides edible books, other entries include "edible book trucks" and "edible bookmarks". The event kicks off with viewing of the entries, each of which has an information card describing the book title, author, and creator of the book art. The "books" are judged by a panel of judges and by public voting. Awards are given in categories like: Most Creative, Least Edible, Best Overall Fiction, Best Overall Non-Fiction, and Best Children's Book.<ref>{{cite book |last = Malanchuk |first = Iona R. |title = Librarians As Community Partners: An Outreach Handbook |editor-first = Carol |editor-last = Smallwood |publisher = ALA Editions |year = 2010 |pages = 3–5 |chapter = Bake a Book and they will come |url = https://books.google.com/?id=O_-iFcSpsMYC&pg=PA5 |isbn = 9780838910061 }}</ref> In 2010, the event is planned to be held on April 15 and the award categories are: Best Overall Entry, Best Book Theme, Best Pun, Best Adult Book, and Best Children's Book.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://blogs.uflib.ufl.edu/news/2010/03/15/call-for-readers-and-edible-book-entries/ |title = Call for Readers and Edible Book Entries |date = March 15, 2010 |publisher = UF Library |access-date = March 18, 2010 }}</ref> [[File:An edible book.jpg|thumb|A cake with exposed layers resembling pages]]
Perkins Library at [[Hastings College]] in Nebraska (US) celebrated [[Banned Books Week]] 2008 by holding an edible book contest. The event invited guests to consume cooked dishes and baked goods that resembled covers of banned books or reflected their content. A reporter sums up the aptly named event: "Our celebration took Sir [[Francis Bacon]]'s famous words quite literally: 'Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and the other few to be chewed and digested.'"<ref>{{cite book |first = Mark R. |last = Gould |title = The Library PR Handbook: High-Impact Communications |publisher = ALA Editions |year = 2009 |pages = 51–52 |chapter = Additional Tasty Examples of Food as a Promotional Tool |url = https://books.google.com/?id=zbUe2e-Z2b4C&pg=PA51 |isbn = 9780838997260 }}</ref>
In 2011, the British newspaper [[Metro (British newspaper)|''Metro'']] ran a story that they would begin producing the newspaper on an edible "Sweet tasting paper" claiming to bring customers "news in the best possible taste". The newspaper later clarified this was nothing more than an [[April Fools' joke]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.worldofdeals.co.uk/other-electronics-deals/top-15-april-fools-2011-shopping-and-deals-pranks |title = Top 15 April Fool’s 2011 Shopping and Deals Pranks |date = April 1, 2011 |access-date = April 7, 2011 }}</ref> {{-}}

<!--[[File:ΓΕΡΟΝΤΑΣ ΠΑΣΤΙΤΣΙΟΣ - ELDER PASTITSIOS Facebook page cover (small).jpg|thumb|"Elder Pastitsios" Facebook page cover]]-->{{Infobox website |name = ΓΕΡΟΝΤΑΣ ΠΑΣΤΙΤΣΙΟΣ - ELDER PASTITSIOS |logo = [[File:ΓΕΡΟΝΤΑΣ ΠΑΣΤΙΤΣΙΟΣ - ELDER PASTITSIOS Facebook page cover (small).jpg|300px]] |logocaption = The page cover featuring the [[flag of Greece]], [[Flying Spaghetti Monster]] as [[Madonna (art)|Madonna]] holding a baby [[dinosaur]], a [[Christian cross]] and "Elder Pastitsios" with [[pastitsio]] face. |screenshot = |collapsible = |collapsetext = |caption = |url = {{URL|www.facebook.com/gerontas.pastitsios}}<ref name=facebook /><ref name=police /> |commercial = No |type = [[Facebook page]] |registration = Optional |language = Greek |num_users = 18,658 subscribers (Jan 2014) |content_license = |owner = |author = |editor = |launch_date = <!--{{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}}--> |alexa = |revenue = |current_status = online |footnotes = }} '''Elder Pastitsios''' ({{lang-ell|Γέρων/Γέροντας Παστίτσιος}}, ''Géron/Gérontas Pastítsios'') is a [[Satire|satirical]] figure of a fictitious [[monk]] who first appeared in a [[Facebook page]]. The satire is mostly based on the famous [[Greeks|Greek]] [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] monk [[Elder Paisios of Mount Athos|Elder Paisios]], with his name and face substituted by [[pastitsio]] — a local [[pasta]] and [[béchamel sauce]] dish, thus combining Greek Orthodox and [[Pastafarian]] imagery.<ref name=facebook>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/gerontas.pastitsios/timeline?filter=2|title=ΓΕΡΟΝΤΑΣ ΠΑΣΤΙΤΣΙΟΣ - ELDER PASTITSIOS|last1=Loizos|first1=Philippos|publisher=Facebook|date=2012|language=Greek|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref> The page ran for about a year until it was closed down after the arrest of its creator for [[blasphemy]] on [[Portal:Current events/2012 September 21|September 21, 2012]]. The case, which started as a Facebook [[Flaming (Internet)|flame]], reached the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek Parliament]] twice and created a strong local as well as international [[political]] impact.
==Background== The main satire of the page revolved around [[Elder Paisios]] (d. 1994), a monk from [[Mount Athos|Holy Mountain]], famous for his spiritual teachings. Much has been written about his person and his prophecies concerning the [[End time]]s, the upbringing of children, couples' relationships, even the [[diet (nutrition)|diet]] Paisios supposedly followed. High-ranking priests as well as believers have proposed that the Elder should be [[glorification|recognised]] as a [[Saint]] by the [[Greek Orthodox church|Orthodox Church]].<ref name=csmonitor /> The page criticised, among others, the exploitation of Paisios by the press and by Orthodox [[website]]s that propagate the alleged [[prophecies]] and teachings of the [[charisma]]tic Elder (according to his followers he had predicted the [[fall of the Soviet Union]] and the recent [[Greek government-debt crisis|Greek crisis]]).<ref name=prin />
The "Elder Pastitsios" page satirised and criticised (with no reported profanity according to the media),<ref name=csmonitor /> various [[Orthodoxy in Greece|religious aspects in Greece]] such as [[infant baptism]], [[religious education]] in schools and the lack of separation between [[church and state]]; these were presented through the eyes of the [[Pastafarian]] [[Parody religion|satirical pseudo-religion]] "Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster", which has been used to lampoon the teaching of [[creationism]] in schools.<ref name=csmonitor />
The page created a [[hoax]] about a posthumous [[miracle]] by Elder Paisios<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fimes.gr/2012/09/gerontas-pastitsios/|script-title=el:Το θαύμα που επινόησε ο Γέρων Παστίτσιος|publisher=fimes.gr|date=September 26, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=The miracle that Elder Pastitsios invented|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> which was submitted to various Orthodox, conservative and far-right blogs in July. The story was based on several existing accounts that were already [[reblogging|circulating online]] and involved the miraculous recovery of a teenager who supposedly woke from a [[coma]] after his mother placed a [[talisman]] with dirt from Elder Paisios’ grave under his pillow.
The story reached 93,800 [[Google search]] results and was reproduced both online and in print, and even became a cover story on the far-right newspaper "Eleftheri Ora".<ref name=seleo /> The 27-year-old page creator would later state that he did this to expose the gullibility of the faithful, and also to show the poor fact-checking done among the religious and conservative [[blogosphere]].<ref name=vaxevanis />
Four days before the page creator's arrest, [[Member of Parliament|MP]] Christos Pappas from the far-right [[Golden Dawn (Greece)|Golden Dawn]] party had brought the page to the attention of the [[Minister of Justice (Greece)|Minister of Justice]] by raising a [[Question time|question]] to the Greek Parliament on September 17.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newpost.gr/post/155764/%CE%95%CF%81%CF%8E%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%92%CE%BF%CF%85%C3%8E-%CE%AE-%CE%B1%CF%80%CF%8C-%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%A7%CF%81%CF%85%CF%83%CE%AE-%CE%91%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%AE-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%BF%CE%BD----%CE%93%CE%AD%CF%81%CE%BF%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B1-%CE%A0%CE%B1%CF%83%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%84%CF%83%CE%B9%CE%BF/|script-title=el:Ερώτηση στη Βουλή από τη Χρυσή Αυγή για τον... Γέροντα Παστίτσιο|publisher=newpost.gr|date=September 22, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Question to the Parliament by Golden Dawn on... Elder Pastitsios|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsnow.gr/article/217811/erotisi-sti-vouli-apo-ti-xrysi-avgi-gia-tin-aisxri-kai-prosvlitiki-selida-sto-facebook-gia-ton-geronta-pasio.html|title=Ερώτηση στη Βουλή από τη Χρυσή Αυγή για την αισχρή και προσβλητική σελίδα στο facebook για τον... Γέροντα Παΐσιο..|publisher=newsnow.gr|date=September 22, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Question to the Parliament by Golden Dawn on the obscene and offensive facebook page for... Elder Paisios ..|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> The police claimed they had already concluded their investigation two days before the question was raised in parliament due to thousands of complaints by Orthodox believers worldwide.<ref name=police>{{cite web|url=http://www.astynomia.gr/index.php?option=ozo_content&lang=%27..%27&perform=view&id=20338&Itemid=965&lang=|title=24-09-2012:H Δίωξη Ηλεκτρονικού Εγκλήματος συνέλαβε 27χρονο ημεδαπό για κακόβουλη βλασφημία και καθύβριση θρησκευμάτων, μέσω του Facebook|publisher=Greek Police|date=September 24, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Cyber Crimes Division arrested 27 year old local for malicious blasphemy and offense of religion, via Facebook|accessdate=October 2, 2012}}</ref>
==Arrest and reaction== On 21 September, the 27-year-old man was arrested in [[Greece]] on charges of malicious blasphemy and offense of [[religion]]<ref name=police /> for the creation of a satirical [[Facebook page]] called "Elder Pastitsios".<ref name=csmonitor /><ref name=prin>{{cite web|url=http://www.prin.gr/2012/09/pastichios.html|script-title=el:Γέρων Παστίτσιος: Σύλληψη κατ'εντολή της Χρυσής Αυγής|last1=Stavroula|first1=Katerina|publisher=Prin newspaper|date=September 30, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Elder Pastitsios: Arrest by order of Golden Dawn|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref><ref name=cfi>{{cite web|url=http://www.centerforinquiry.net/blogs/entry/elder_pastitios_arrest_rekindles_debate_on_blasphemy_laws_in_greece/|title="Elder Pastitsios" Arrest Rekindles Debate on Blasphemy Laws in Greece|last1=Fidalgo|first1=Paul|publisher=Center For Inquiry|date=September 28, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref name=jakarta>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/international/greek-police-smite-facebook-man-for-taunting-orthodox-monk/546329|title=Greek Police Smite Facebook Man for Taunting Orthodox Monk|publisher=The Jakarta Globe|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=October 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/24/gerontas-pastitsios-pastafarian-facebook-greece-elder-paisios_n_1909511.html?ir=Religion|title='Gerontas Pastitsios' Pastafarian Facebook Page Leads To Blasphemy Arrest In Greece|last1=Jauregui|first1=Andres|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012|work=Huffington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heavy.com/news/2012/09/greece-arrests-pastafarian-blasphemy-monk-facebook/|title=Greece Arrests Pastafarian for Blasphemy after he Mocked a Monk on Facebook|last1=Prospect|first1=Neil|publisher=heavy.com|date=September 26, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zgeek.com/forum/index.php?threads/pastafarian-arrested-for-blasphemy.174964/|title=Pastafarian arrested for blasphemy|publisher=zgeek.com|date=September 26, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2012/09/29/greek-pastafarian-arrested-for.html|title=Greek Pastafarian arrested for "Cyber Crimes"|last1=Doctorow|first1=Cory|publisher=boingboing.net|date=September 29, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2012/09/24/golden-dawn-presses-arrest-for-blasphemy/|title=Golden Dawn Presses Arrest for Paisios Blasphemy|last1=Papapostolou|first1=A.|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/387369/20120924/elder-paisios-geron-pastitsios-greece-blasphemy-orthodox.htm|title=Greece: Golden Dawn 'Force' Arrest over Monk Elder Paisios Facebook Page Blasphemy|last1=Mezzofiore|first1=Gianluca|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keeptalkinggreece.com/2012/09/24/greek-police-arrests-man-27-for-blaspheming-a-monk-on-facebook/|title=Greek Police Arrests Man, 27, for Blaspheming a Monk on Facebook|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://greekvoices.blogspot.gr/2012/09/blog-post_187.html|script-title=el:ΥΠΟΘΕΣΗ ΠΑΣΤΙΤΣΙΟΣ:Η "ΕΛΛΑΔΑ" ΓΙΝΕΤΑΙ ΙΡΑΝ ΜΕ ΤΙΣ ΕΥΛΟΓΙΕΣ ΤΗΣ ΧΡΥΣΗΣ ΑΥΓΗΣ!!|publisher=greekvoices|date=September 27, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=The Pastitsios case: Greece becomes Iran with the eulogies of Golden Dawn|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/news/greece-geron-pastitsios-elder-paisios/|title=Greek authorities charge man with blashemy for Facebook page|publisher=The Daily Dot|date=September 25, 2012|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref><ref name=protothema /> Blasphemy in Greece carries a fine of up to 3,000 €, and up to 2 years imprisonment.
The news of the arrest created a worldwide interest in the case with the [[Twitter]] [[hashtag]] #FreeGeronPastitsios becoming a global trending topic and a relevant [[petition]] by the [[Humanism|Humanist]] Union of Greece has received over 10,000 signatures so far on [[Change.org]].<ref name=seleo>{{cite web|url=http://www.seleo.gr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70748:2012-09-26-08-02-56&catid=74:sites&Itemid=54|script-title=el:Πως ο Γέροντας Παστίτσιος κορόιδεψε με ένα θαύμα-μαϊμού την Χρυσή Αυγή|publisher=seleo.gr|date=September 26, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=How Elder Pastitsios mocked Golden Dawn with a fake miracle|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_25/09/2012_462786|title=Greek police arrest man behind Facebook page satirizing 'mystical' priest|publisher=ekathimerini.gr|date=September 25, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref>
In a [[web television]] interview<ref name=vaxevanis>{{cite video|title=ΑΥΤΟΣ ΕΙΝΑΙ Ο ΠΑΣΤΙΤΣΙΟΣ! (This is Pastitsios!)|publisher=Kostas Vaxevanis|location=Athens, Greece|date=September 27, 2012|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mLGalea0NnM|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> after his arrest, the page owner said that the evidence that led the e-crimes bureau of the Greek police to him were all provided by Facebook. Pan-Euro communications manager of Facebook, Iain Mackenzie wrote that Facebook disclosed basic subscriber information in response to a Greek [[court order]] without knowing what type of charges the user was subject to.<ref name=csmonitor>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2012/1002/Blasphemy-in-democracy-s-birthplace-Greece-arrests-Facebook-user|title=Blasphemy in democracy's birthplace? Greece arrests Facebook user.|last1=Apostolou|first1=Nikolia|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|date=October 2, 2012|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref> According to article 19 of the [[Constitution of Greece|Greek Constitution]], limiting of confidentiality of communications is allowed only in cases of "particularly serious crimes." The Greek [[criminal code]] translates "particularly serious crimes" as [[Felony|felonies]] while "malicious blasphemy and offense of religion" is considered a [[misdemeanor]].<ref name=prin /><ref name=pandora>{{cite web|url=http://www.koutipandoras.gr/?p=26337|title=Το Facebook νίπτει τα χείρας του για τον "Παστίτσιο"|publisher=To Kouti Tis Pandoras|date=October 3, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Facebook washes its hands of "Pastitsios"|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref>
Following the publication of the arrest, Greece's [[Coalition government|ruling coalition]] junior partner [[Democratic Left (Greece)|Democratic Left]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iefimerida.gr/news/69211/%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81-%CE%BC%CE%B5-%CF%84%CE%B7-%CF%83%CF%8D%CE%BB%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%88%CE%B7-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%C2%AB%CE%B3%CE%AD%CF%81%CE%BF%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B1-%CF%80%CE%B1%CF%83%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%84%CF%83%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%85%C2%BB-%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%BA%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82-%CE%B1%CE%BA%CE%BF%CE%BB%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%B5%CE%AF-%CF%84%CE%B7-%CF%87%CF%81%CF%85%CF%83%CE%AE-%CE%B1%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%AE|script-title=el:ΔΗΜΑΡ: Με τη σύλληψη του "Παστίτσιου" το κράτος ακολουθεί τη Χρυσή Αυγή|publisher=iefimerida.gr|date=September 24, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Democratic Left: With the arrest of "Pastitsios" the State follows Golden Dawn|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> and the [[Greek Communist Party]] strongly denounced the arrest while leftist primary [[Opposition (politics)|opposition]] [[Political party|party]] [[SYRIZA]] raised a second question to the parliament, this time concerning the legality of the arrest and the freedom of expression.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsbomb.gr/politikh/story/237811/erotisi-syriza-sti-voyli-gia-ton-geronta-pastitsio|script-title=el:Ερώτηση ΣΥΡΙΖΑ στη Βουλή για τον "Γέροντα Παστίτσιο"|publisher=newsbomb.gr|date=September 26, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=SYRIZA Questions Parliament on "Geron Pastitsios"|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> The parliamentary spokesman of SYRIZA and MP [[Dimitrios Papadimoulis]] stated that he would appear as a defense [[witness]] in the [[trial]] of the arrestee and even the [[metropolitan bishop]] of [[Thessaloniki]], Anthimos said on a radio show that he did "not agree with the [[prosecution]], better to leave him alone. No one can usurp the [[faith]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tanea.gr/ellada/article/?aid=4754456|script-title=el:Σε δίκη παραπέμφθηκε ο 27χρονος για τον "Γέροντα Παστίτσιο"|publisher=Ta Nea|date=September 25, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=In court the 27 years old for "Elder Pastitsios"|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> Supporters of the arrestee held a small [[protest]] in front of the Greek Parliament on September 28<ref>{{cite video|title=Blogger supporters angry at blasphemy arrest in Greece|publisher=athensnewsweb|location=Athens, Greece|date=September 28, 2012|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RXSTsbUgg6c|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref> and on the same night another one in the centre of [[Athens]] parodying an Orthodox [[litany]].<ref name=prin /><ref>{{cite video|title=Περιφορά Ιερού Σκηνώματος (τάβλα) Γέροντος Παστίτσιου στη χριστεπώνυμη συνοικία των Εξαρχείων (Procession of the Holy Relic (stiff) of Elder Pastitsios in the christian named Athenian neighborhood of Exarchia)|publisher=risinggalaxy|location=Athens, Greece|date=September 28, 2012|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m7UgWsWlHq4|accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref>
The page creator mentioned that he plans on focusing his future [[activism]] on the repeal of Greece's blasphemy laws.<ref name=vaxevanis />
==Conviction==
On January 16, 2014, the creator of the original "Elder Pastitsios" website was found guilty of "repeatedly insulting religion" and was [[Sentence (law)|sentenced]] to ten months in [[prison|jail]], [[Suspended sentence|suspended]]<ref name=Ethnos>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22768&subid=2&pubid=63949339|script-title=el:Δέκα μήνες στον ...«Γέροντα Παστίτσιο» |publisher=Pegasus Network|date=January 17, 2014|language=Greek|trans-title=Ten months to... "the Elder Pastitsios"|accessdate=January 17, 2014}}</ref><ref name=TheGuardianJan2014>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/17/facebook-page-mocking-greek-orthodox-monk-jail-blasphemy# |title=Facebook page mocking Greek Orthodox monk leads to jail sentence |publisher=The Guardian |date=January 17, 2014 |accessdate=January 17, 2014}} </ref><ref name=tvxsJan2014>{{cite web |url=http://tvxs.gr/news/ellada/deka-mines-gia-ton-geronta-pastitsio |script-title=el:Δέκα μήνες για τον Γέροντα Παστίτσιο |language=Greek |trans-title=Ten months for Elder Pastitsios |last1=Michos |first1=Nikos |publisher=tvxs |date=January 16, 2014 |accessdate=January 17, 2014}} </ref> while the [[prosecutor]] had recommended a smaller sentence.<ref name=ethnosJan2014>{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22768&subid=2&pubid=63949339 |script-title=el:Καταδίκη του «Γέροντα Παστίτσιου» |language=Greek |trans-title=Conviction of "Elder Pastitsios" |last1= |first1= |publisher=Ethnos newspaper |date=January 16, 2014 |accessdate=January 17, 2014}} </ref> In the 2017 retrial, however, the court acquitted Loizos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efsyn.gr/arthro/apallahtike-o-gerontas-pastitsios|title=Απαλλάχτηκε ο "Γέροντας Παστίτσιος" (English: "Elder Pastitsios" is acquitted)|publisher=Efsyn.gr|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref>
==Internet meme== The idea of creating fictional characters based on Paisios quickly became a brief [[internet meme]] featured in mainstream media and even in [[T-shirt]]s, occasionally as a reaction to the arrest, and support to the page creator. Such characters include "Elder [[Paris]]ios" with monk's head substituted by the [[Eiffel Tower]],<ref name=protothema>{{cite web|url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=225181|script-title=el:Συνελήφθη ο… Παστίτσιος, ήρθε και ο… Παρίσιος|publisher=Proto Thema newspaper|date=September 24, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=Pastitsios arrested, here comes... Parisios|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref> "Elder Papisios" from the Greek word for duck ({{lang-ell|παπί}}, ''papí'') and the face of [[Daffy Duck]],<ref name=axortagos>{{cite web|url=http://www.axortagos.gr/meta-geronta-pastitsio-erxetai-papisios.html|script-title=el:Μετά το γέροντα Παστίτσιο έρχεται ο… Παπίσιος|publisher=axortagos.gr|date=September 25, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=After Elder Pastitsios here comes... Papisios|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref> and many others.<ref name=msn>{{cite web|url=http://news.gr.msn.com/world/%CE%BC%CE%B5%CF%84%CE%AC-%CF%84%CE%BF%CE%BD-%CE%B3%CE%AD%CF%81%CE%BF%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B1-%CF%80%CE%B1%CF%83%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%84%CF%83%CE%B9%CE%BF-%CF%84%CE%B9-1?page=14#image=1|script-title=el:Μετά τον Γέροντα Παστίτσιο, τι;|publisher=MSN News|date=September 27, 2012|language=Greek|trans-title=After Elder Pastitsios, what?|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Paranormal}} The '''Enfield Poltergeist''' is the name given to claimed [[supernatural]] activity at 284 Green Street, a [[council house]] in [[Brimsdown]], [[London Borough of Enfield|Enfield]], [[England]] between 1977 and 1979 involving two sisters, aged 11 and 13.<ref name="Storr 2015">Storr, Will. (2015). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/11571607/The-real-story-of-the-Enfield-Haunting.html "The Real Story of the Enfield Haunting"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 3 May 2015.</ref> Some members of the [[Society for Psychical Research]] such as inventor [[Maurice Grosse]] and writer [[Guy Lyon Playfair]] believed the haunting to be genuine, while others such as [[Anita Gregory]] and [[John Beloff]] were "unconvinced" and found evidence the girls had faked incidents for the benefit of reporters. Members of the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]], including stage magicians such as [[Milbourne Christopher]], [[Joe Nickell]] and Bob Couttie, reviewed the case and criticised paranormal investigators for being overly credulous whilst also identifying features of the case as being indicative of a [[hoax]].<ref>Couttie, Bob. (1988). ''Forbidden Knowledge: The Paranormal Paradox''. Lutterworth Press. p. 62. {{ISBN|978-0-7188-2686-4}} "The case remains very controversial. Grosse, Playfair, Hasted and others believe it was genuine, Anita Gregory and other members of the SPR were unconvinced. Magicians and ventriloquists came to the conclusion that Janet was cheating."</ref><ref name=NickellCSI>{{cite web |last=Nickell |first=Joe |title=Enfield Poltergeist |url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/enfield_poltergeist |website=CSI |publisher=Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal |accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="Hyde 2015">[[Deborah Hyde|Hyde, Deborah]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/may/01/the-enfield-poltergeist-a-skeptic-speaks The Enfield 'Poltergeist': A Sceptic Speaks]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 1 May 2015. Retrieved 2 May 2015.</ref>
The story attracted considerable press coverage in British newspapers such as the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', and has been the subject of books, featured in [[television]] documentaries, and dramatised in [[horror film]]s.
==Claims== In August 1977 single parent Peggy Hodgson called police to her rented home in Enfield after two of her four children said that furniture was moving and knocking sounds were heard on walls. The children included Margaret, age 14, and Janet, 11. A police constable said that she saw a chair "wobble and slide".<ref name=NickellCSI/> Later claims included disembodied voices, loud noises, thrown rocks and toys, overturned chairs, and children [[levitation (paranormal)|levitating]].<ref name="Storr 2015"/> Over a period of 18 months, more than 30 people, including neighbours, psychic researchers and journalists, said they saw heavy furniture moving of its own accord, objects being thrown across a room and the daughters seeming to levitate several feet off the ground. Many also heard—and recorded—unexplained knocking noises and a gruff voice.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Reunion, The Enfield Poltergeist|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09yck6b |website=BBC Radio 4 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> The activity in the house attracted considerable press attention and the story was covered in British newspapers such as the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' until reports came to an end in 1979.<ref name=NickellCSI/><ref name="Nickell2012">{{cite book |author=Joe Nickell |title=The Science of Ghosts: Searching for Spirits of the Dead |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oGS67QhECywC&pg=PT281 |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=Prometheus Books |isbn=978-1-61614-586-6 |pages=281–}}</ref>
==Investigations== ===Paranormal=== [[Society for Psychical Research]] members [[Maurice Grosse]] and [[Guy Lyon Playfair]] reported "curious whistling and barking noises coming from Janet's general direction." Although Playfair maintained the [[haunting]] was genuine and wrote in his later book ''This House Is Haunted: The True Story of a Poltergeist'' (1980) that an "entity" was to blame for the disturbances, he often doubted the children's veracity and wondered if they were playing tricks and exaggerating. Still, Grosse and Playfair believed that even though some of the alleged [[poltergeist]] activity was faked by the girls, other incidents were genuine.<ref name=NickellCSI/><ref name="Nickell2012"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Playfair|first=Guy Lyon|title=This House Is Haunted: The True Story of a Poltergeist|publisher=Stein and Day|year=1980|isbn=978-0-7387-1867-5}}</ref> Janet was detected in trickery; a video camera in the room next door caught her bending spoons and attempting to bend an iron bar.<ref>Guiley, Rosemary (1994). ''The Guinness Encyclopedia of Ghosts and Spirits''. Guinness World Records Limited. p. 109. {{ISBN|978-0851127484}}</ref><ref>Clarkson, Michael. (2006). ''Poltergeists: Examining Mysteries of the Paranormal''. Firefly Books. p. 135. {{ISBN|978-1554071593}} "Anita Gregory, of the Society for Psychical Research, who had spent just a short time at the Hodgson home, said the mysterious men's voices were simply the result of Janet and Margaret putting bed sheets to their mouths. In addition, Gregory said that a video camera had caught Janet attempting to bend spoons and an iron bar by force and "practicing" levitation by bouncing up and down on her bed."</ref> Grosse had observed Janet banging a broom handle on the ceiling and hiding his tape-recorder.<ref name="Couttie 1988">Couttie, Bob. (1988). ''Forbidden Knowledge: The Paranormal Paradox''. Lutterworth Press. pp. 62-64. {{ISBN|978-0-7188-2686-4}}</ref> According to Playfair, one of Janet's voices she called "Bill" displayed a "habit of suddenly changing the topic—it was a habit Janet also had".<ref name="Hyde 2015"/>
When Janet and Margaret admitted "pranking" to reporters, Grosse and Playfair compelled the girls to retract their confession.<ref name=NickellCSI/> They were mocked by other researchers for being easily duped.<ref>Carlson, H. G. (1994). ''Mysteries of the Unexplained''. Contemporary Books. p. 46. {{ISBN|978-0809234974}}</ref>
The psychical researcher [[Renée Haynes]] had noted that doubts were raised about the alleged poltergeist voice at the Second International SPR Conference at Cambridge in 1978, where video cassettes from the case were examined.<ref>Haynes, Renée. (1982). ''The Society for Psychical Research 1882-1982: A History''. MacDonald & Co. p. 112. {{ISBN|978-0356078755}}</ref> The SPR investigator [[Anita Gregory]] stated the Enfield poltergeist case had been "overrated", characterising several episodes of the girls' behaviour as "suspicious" and speculated that the girls had "staged" some incidents for the benefit of reporters seeking a sensational story.<ref name=NickellCSI/><ref name="Nickell2012"/> [[John Beloff]], a former president of the SPR, investigated and suggested Janet was practicing [[ventriloquism]]. Both Beloff and Gregory came to the conclusion that Janet and Margaret were playing tricks on the investigators.<ref>Clarkson, Michael. (2006). ''Poltergeists: Examining Mysteries of the Paranormal''. Firefly Books. p. 131. {{ISBN|978-1554071593}}</ref>
===Other=== American magician [[Milbourne Christopher]] briefly investigated, failed to observe anything that could be called paranormal and was dismayed by what he felt was suspicious activity on the part of Janet. Christopher would later conclude that "the poltergeist was nothing more than the antics of a little girl who wanted to cause trouble and who was very, very, clever."<ref name=NickellCSI/> Ventriloquist [[Ray Alan]] visited the house and concluded that Janet's male voices were simply vocal tricks.<ref name=NickellCSI/>
==Sceptical Interpretations== ===Criticisms of investigations=== Sceptic [[Joe Nickell]] examined the findings of paranormal investigators and criticised them for being overly credulous; when a supposedly disembodied demonic voice was heard, Playfair noted that, "as always Janet's lips hardly seemed to be moving."
Nickell states that a remote-controlled still camera—the photographer was not present in the room with the girls—timed to take a picture every fifteen seconds was shown by investigator [[Melvin Harris]] to reveal "pranking" by the girls. He argues that a photo allegedly depicting Janet levitating actually shows her bouncing off the bed as if it were a trampoline. Harris called the photos examples of common "gymnastics", and said "It's worth remembering that Janet was a school sports champion!"
Nickell asserted that a [[tape recorder]] malfunction that Grosse attributed to supernatural activity and [[Society for Psychical Research]] president [[David Fontana]] described as an occurrence "which appeared to defy the laws of mechanics" was a peculiar threading jam capable of occurring with older model [[reel to reel]] tape recorders.<ref name="Nickell 3">{{cite web |last=Nickell |first=Joe |title=The Haunted Tape Recorder |url=http://www.csicop.org/sb/show/haunted_tape_recorder |website=CSI |publisher=Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal |accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>
Nickell also claimed that [[Demonology|demonologist]] [[Ed and Lorraine Warren|Ed Warren]] was "notorious for exaggerating and even making up incidents in such cases, often transforming a "haunting" case into one of "demonic possession".<ref name=NickellCSI/>
In 2015, [[Deborah Hyde]] commented that there was no solid evidence for the Enfield poltergeist: "... the first thing to note is that the occurrences didn't happen under controlled circumstances. People frequently see what they expect to see, their senses being organised and shaped by their prior experiences and beliefs."<ref name="Hyde 2015"/>
===Response to claims=== Sceptics have argued that the alleged poltergeist voice that originated from Janet was produced by [[false vocal cords]] above the [[larynx]] and had the [[phraseology]] and [[vocabulary]] of a child.<ref name="Couttie 1988"/> In a television interview for [[BBC Scotland]], Janet was observed to gain attention by waving her hand, and then putting her hand in front of her mouth while a claimed "disembodied" voice was heard. During the interview both girls were asked the question "How does it feel to be haunted by a poltergeist?" Janet replied "It's not haunted" and Margaret, in a hushed tone, interrupted "Shut up". These factors have been regarded by sceptics as evidence against the case.<ref name="Couttie 1988"/>
As "a magician experienced in the dynamics of trickery", Nickell examined Playfair's account as well as contemporary press clippings. He noted that the supposed poltergeist "tended to act only when it was not being watched" and concluded that the incidents were best explained as children's pranks.<ref name=NickellCSI/> In an interview with the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', the adult Janet admitted that she and her sister had faked "2 percent" of the phenomena. This prompted Nickell to comment in another publication, "the evidence suggests that this figure is closer to 100 percent".<ref name="Nickell2012"/>
Although Maurice Grosse made tape recordings of Janet and believed no trickery was involved, the magician Bob Couttie said, "he made some of the recordings available to me and, having listened to them very carefully, I came to the conclusion that there was nothing in what I had heard that was beyond the capabilities of an imaginative teenager."<ref name="Couttie 1988"/> An article by psychology professor [[Chris French]] in 2016 described five reasons why he believed the case to have been a hoax.<ref>[http://www.timeout.com/london/blog/five-reasons-why-londons-most-famous-poltergeist-case-is-a-hoax-061616 "Five reasons why London's most famous poltergeist case is a hoax"]. Chris French.</ref>
==In popular culture== *In 1992 the [[BBC]] aired a [[mockumentary]] entitled ''[[Ghostwatch]]'', written by Stephen Volk and based on the Enfield Poltergeist.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jagodzinski|first=Jan|title=Youth Fantasies: The Perverse Landscape of the Media|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2004|page=145|isbn=978-1-4039-6164-8}}</ref> *In March 2007 [[Channel 4]] aired a documentary about the Enfield poltergeist, entitled ''Interview with a Poltergeist''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-440048/Suburban-poltergeist-A-30-year-silence-broken.html|title=Suburban poltergeist: A 30-year silence is broken|last=Penman|first=Danny|date=5 March 2007|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London}}</ref> *The Enfield poltergeist has been featured in episodes of [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] series ''[[Strange but True?]]'' and ''[[Extreme Ghost Stories]]''. *The Enfield poltergeist was the subject of the 2015 [[Sky Living]] television series ''[[The Enfield Haunting]]'', which was broadcast from 4–17 May 2015,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3033319/Estate-agents-fright-life-fake-haunted-house-promote-Sky-Living-s-Enfield-Haunting.html|title=Petrified estate agents get the fright of their lives in haunted house practical joke (and the men have the most hysterical reactions)|last=Morgan|first=Maybelle|date=10 April 2015|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London}}</ref> *The 2016 film ''[[The Conjuring 2]]'' is based on the case.<ref name="Hawkes">{{cite web|last1=Hawkes|first1=Rebecca|title=What did the Enfield Haunting have to do with Ed and Lorraine Warren?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/the-conjuring-2--the-enfield-poltergeist/haunting-ed-lorraine-warren-true-story/|website=Telegraph.co.uk|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> *In 2018 the [[BBC Radio 4]] programme ''The Reunion'' revisited the case, with interviews with people who were involved.<ref>{{Cite episode |title= The Enfield Poltergeist |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09yck6b |access-date=14 April 2018 |series=The Reunion |author=Whistledown |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC Radio 4]] |date=8 April 2018}}</ref>

'''FESPA''' is a federation of [[trade association]]s and an organiser of exhibitions and conferences for the [[screenprinting]] and [[digital printing]] industry. The name originally stood for '''Federation of European Screen Printers Associations''', but, with the advent of digital technology, FESPA is now known by its acronym.
==Overview== FESPA is a "federation of global screen, textile and [[digital printing]] trade associations" servicing its members and the print community at large. FESPA are also an events and [[exhibitions]] organiser for the [[Wide-format printer|wide format]], [[screenprinting|screen]], textile and digital printing community.<ref>http://www.earthisland.co.uk/#!Fespa-2015-attendance-up-17/cuhk/556c23f80cf298b2d3f64c93</ref>
The organisation provides a forum for information exchange between member associations resulting in help from the larger to the smaller Associations in recruitment, training and technical studies.<ref>http://www.printwearandpromotion.co.uk/index.php/fespa-launches-free-technology-guides-for-association-members/</ref>
It also runs a number of events and community outreach programmes, including industry research<ref>http://whattheythink.com/news/73311-fespa-launches-free-technology-guides-association-members/</ref> and educational programmes for students,<ref>http://www.adcomms.co.uk/media-centre/fespa-eurasia-2015/fespa-progresses-regional-re-investment-programme-with-support-for-next-generation-turkish-printers</ref> vehicle wrapping competitions,<ref>http://www.wrap-masters.com</ref> Awards,<ref>http://www.printweek.com/print-week/news/1151658/uks-fespa-award-winners-hail-benefits-of-triumph</ref> networking events <ref>http://www.innovationintextiles.com/fespa-global-summit-2014/</ref> and design conferences.
==Heritage== FESPA was formed as a 'non-profit' organisation in 1962 by a group of screen printing associations whose aim was to create a platform to share knowledge on [[screen printing]] technology in Europe.
The original membership consisted of 8 representatives, including [[Michel Caza]] - fine art printer to artists including [[Andy Warhol]] and [[Salvador Dalí]].<ref>https://www.sgia.org/person/caza-michel</ref> As the organisation grew, more associations joined. Current membership stands at around 40 national associations.<ref>http://www.fespa.com/fespa-associations.html</ref>
The current president is Turkey's Yaşar Güvenen, who was elected in 2014 and took office in 2015.<ref>http://www.printweek.com/print-week/news/1151538/g-venen-named-as-new-fespa-president-at-awards-gala</ref>
==Research== FESPA produces market research on the trends, challenges, opportunities and threats confronting the community in partnership with InfoTrends – a research organisation for the print trade.
The reports provide analysis of the state of the marketplace and are funded through the organisation's 'Profit for Purpose' initiative.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=fsb.org.uk |url=http://www.adcomms.co.uk/cpressr2.aspx?prid=8400 |title=Results From First-Ever FESPA World Wide Survey Now Available |accessdate=2007-05-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090526060745/http://www.adcomms.co.uk/cpressr2.aspx?prid=8400 |archivedate=2009-05-26 |df= }}</ref>
