{{about|the British National Railway Museum}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox museum |name = National Railway Museum |image = National Railway Museum.svg |established = {{start date and age|df=yes|1975}} |location = Leeman Road, [[York]], England |type = [[Railway museum]] |visitors = 718,000 (2017)<ref>{{cite web|title=ALVA - Association of Leading Visitor Attractions|url=http://www.alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=423|website=www.alva.org.uk|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> |director = Judith McNicol |website = {{URL|https://www.railwaymuseum.org.uk/}} |network = NMSI }} The '''National Railway Museum''' ('''NRM''') is a [[museum]] in [[York]] forming part of the British [[Science Museum Group]] of National Museums and telling the story of [[rail transport]] in Britain and its impact on society. It has won many awards, including the [[European Museum of the Year Award]] in 2001. It is the home of the national collection of historically significant railway vehicles, as well as a collection of other artefacts and both written and pictorial records. {{TOC limit|2}}
==Overview== The National Railway Museum in York displays a collection of over 100 [[locomotive]]s and nearly 300 other items of [[rolling stock]], virtually all of which either ran on the railways of [[Great Britain]] or were built there. Also on the {{convert|20|acre|ha|1|abbr=on}} site are many hundreds of thousands of other items and records of social, technical, artistic and historical interest, exhibited mostly in three large halls of a former motive power depot next to the [[East Coast Main Line]], near [[York railway station]].
It is the largest museum of its type in Britain, attracting 727,000 visitors during the 2014/15 financial year<ref>{{cite web | year = | url = https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/431351/MUSEUM_FIGURES_April_figures__published_June_2015_.xlsx | title = Museums and Galleries Monthly Statistics (L 263) | work = UK Government Data sets | date = 4 June 2015 | author = | publisher = Department for Culture, Media & Sport | accessdate = 21 June 2015 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150621221036/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/431351/MUSEUM_FIGURES_April_figures__published_June_2015_.xlsx | archivedate = 21 June 2015 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> (the largest in the world in terms of floor area of exhibition buildings is [[Musée Français du Chemin de Fer|La Cité du Train]] in the French town of [[Mulhouse]], although this attracts far fewer visitors than the National Railway Museum).
The National Railway Museum was established on its present site, the former York North [[locomotive depot]], in 1975, when it took over the former [[British Rail]]ways collection located in [[Clapham]] and the York Railway Museum located off Queen Street, immediately to the southeast of the railway station;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/AboutUs/history.aspx|title=About us - National Railway Museum|author=|date=|website=National Railway Museum}}</ref> since then, the collection has continued to grow. {{Clear}} {{Wide image|NRM Great Hall merge2.jpg|600px|A panorama of locomotives arranged around the turntable in the Great Hall|}}
The museum is a short walk from the railway station in York, either on the road or via a staircase from the rear of the platforms. A "roadtrain" runs from the city centre (near [[York Minster]]) to the museum on Leeman Road during half term, holidays and summer. [[York Park and Ride]] also serve the museum from the car park entrance, on Line 2 (Rawcliffe Bar-York). Admission to the museum has been free since 2001. It is open daily from 10 am to 6 pm from February to November and 10 am to 5 pm during the winter months.
[[National Railway Museum Shildon|Locomotion]] – the National Railway Museum in [[Shildon]], [[County Durham]] was opened in October 2004 and is operated by the NRM in conjunction with [[Durham County Council]].<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Prime Minister opens Shildon Locomotion museum |magazine=[[The Railway Magazine]] |issue=1244 |date=December 2004 |page=5 }}</ref> It houses more of the National Collection in a new building and a historic site around the former workshop of [[Timothy Hackworth]] and in the most recent full year for which figures have been published (2011–2012), it attracted more than 210,000 visitors.
<gallery style="text-align:left" mode="packed" widths="180px" heights="180px"> National Railway Museum, York (1981).JPG|The Great Hall (1981) Mallardnrmyork.JPG|[[Mallard (locomotive)|4468 ''Mallard'']] at the National Railway Museum York (2009) 31018BRD.JPG|[[British Rail Class 31|Class 31]] No. 31018 on display in the Great Hall (2006) 089-SFEC-YORK-20070827.JPG| A Japanese [[0 Series Shinkansen]] (No.22-141) at the NRM (2007) Hogwarts_Express_at_York.jpg|Visiting [[Hogwarts Express]] engine [[GWR 4900 Class 5972 Olton Hall|5972 ''Olton Hall'']] (2004) George Stephenson Statue National Railway Museum.JPG|Statue of [[George Stephenson]] in the Great Hall </gallery>
==National Collection== {{See also|List of rolling stock items in the UK National Collection}} [[File:Mallard Record Plate 01.jpg|thumb|[[LNER Class A4 4468 Mallard|''Mallard'']] record plate]] [[File:Chinese Government Railways Class KF7 No 607 National Railway Museum York 15 March 2009.jpg|thumb|[[China Railways KF]] No. 607]] There are approximately 280 [[rail vehicles]] in the National Collection, with around 100 being at York at any one time and the remainder divided between [[Shildon Locomotion Museum|Locomotion]] at [[Shildon]] and other museums and [[heritage railway]]s. The earliest are [[wagonway]] vehicles of about 1815. The permanent display includes "Palaces on Wheels", a collection of [[Royal Train]] saloons from [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]]'s early trains through to those used by [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] up to the 1970s, among them some of the first rail vehicles to be set aside for preservation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kumar|first= Amba|title=Stately Progress: Royal Train Travel since 1840|publisher=National Railway Museum|location=York|year=1997|isbn=1-872826-09-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Jenkinson|first= David|last2=Townend|first2= Gwen|title=Palaces on Wheels: Royal Carriages at the National Railway Museum|publisher=H.M.S.O|location=London|year=1981|isbn=0-11-290366-5}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Ellis|first= C. Hamilton|title=Royal Journey|publisher=British Transport Commission|location=London|year=1953}}</ref> Other key exhibits normally to be seen at York include the 1846 [[Furness Railway No. 3]] "Coppernob" locomotive, and the more modern express passenger [[steam locomotive]]s [[London and North Eastern Railway]] [[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|Class A3 No. 4472 ''Flying Scotsman'']] (added to the collection in 2004),<ref>{{cite book|last=Hughes|first= Geoffrey|title=Flying Scotsman: the people’s engine|publisher=Friends of the National Railway Museum Enterprises|location=York|year=2004|isbn=0-9546685-3-7}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Roden|first= Andrew|title=Flying Scotsman|location=London|publisher=Aurum|year=2007|isbn=978-1-84513-241-5}}</ref> its streamlined sister [[LNER Class A4 4468 Mallard|Class A4 No. 4468 ''Mallard'']] and [[London, Midland and Scottish Railway]] [[LMS Princess Coronation Class 6229 Duchess of Hamilton|Princess Coronation Class No. 6229 ''Duchess of Hamilton'']].<ref>{{cite book|last=Blakemore|first= Michael|last2= Rutherford|first2= Michael|title=46229 Duchess of Hamilton|publisher=Newburn House|year=1984}}</ref> ''Flying Scotsman'' is among the exhibits intended for operation on the [[National Rail]] network from time to time.
The museum has imported several major vehicles for display: the [[Rail transport in the People's Republic of China|Chinese]] Class KF7 [[4-8-4#The British 4-8-4 for China|4–8–4]] locomotive donated in 1981 was built in Britain and the ''[[Wagons-Lits]]'' [[sleeping car]] donated in 1980 had been used on the Paris-London ''[[Night Ferry]]'' service. The single exception to the rule of exhibits associated with Britain is the Japanese [[0 Series Shinkansen]] leading vehicle which was donated to the museum by the [[West Japan Railway Company]] in 2001<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1400749.stm|title=High-speed train crawls to new home|date=21 June 2001|work=BBC News|accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref> and which now forms part of an award-winning display, and is the only Shinkansen vehicle on exhibit outside Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collection.sciencemuseum.org.uk/objects/co8001129/west-japan-railways-shinkansen-bullet-train-1976-powered-unit|title=West Japan Railways Shinkansen 'Bullet Train', 1976 |accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref>
Rail vehicles on display are exchanged from time to time with other organisations, and examples of new-build stock from the current industry sometimes visit the museum for short periods. [[File:National rail museum 8568.jpg|thumb|Some of the locomotives on display at the National Railway Museum, York]] Other physically large exhibits are the [[Stockton and Darlington Railway]] [[Gaunless Bridge]] and several stationary winding engines used on railway inclines.
The many other two and three-dimensional elements of the collection include signalling equipment, road vehicles, ship models, [[poster]]s, drawings and other artwork,<ref> {{cite book|editor-last=Roe|editor-first= Sonia|title=Oil paintings in public ownership in North Yorkshire|publisher=[[The Public Catalogue Foundation]]|location=London|year=2006}}</ref> [[Edmondson railway ticket|tickets]], nameplates, staff uniforms, [[clock]]s, [[watch]]es, [[furniture]] and equipment from railway companies' [[hotel]]s, refreshment rooms and offices (including company [[Seal (device)|seals]]) and a wide range of models, some of which are operated on the museum's [[O scale]] [[Rail transport modelling|model railway]] (originated in 1982).<ref> {{cite magazine |title=Treasure in Reserve|magazine=Railway Magazine|pages=41–52|date=June 1993}}</ref>
===Search Engine=== The National Railway Museum holds a large open library and archive of railway related material. This includes an internationally significant collection of locomotive and rolling stock [[engineering drawing]]s from railway works and independent manufacturing companies. Copies of many of these engineering drawings are sold to the heritage railway movement to assist with their new build locomotive and restoration projects. They are also sold to modellers who can use the drawing to produce accurate scale models. The library holds more than 20,000 books<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/ResearchAndArchive/archiveandlibrarycollections/Books.aspx |title=NRM Library Books |accessdate= 18 July 2012}}</ref> and 800 journals of which around 300 are active.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/ResearchAndArchive/archiveandlibrarycollections/Journals.aspx |title=NRM Library Journal Collection|accessdate= 18 July 2012}}</ref> The archive also holds a large collection of technical and test records, as well as timetables including a large number of [[Bradshaw's Railway Guide|Bradshaw timetables]]. The archives also hold some 1.75 million photographs covering the earliest era of photography to the modern day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/ResearchAndArchive/archiveandlibrarycollections/Photographs.aspx |title=NRM Photograph Collections|accessdate= 18 July 2012}}</ref> These include official collections from railway companies and collections from enthusiasts like [[Eric Treacy]] and [[H. Gordon Tidey]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Bartholomew|first= Ed |last2=Blakemore|first2= Michael|title=Railways in Focus: photographs from the National Railway Museum collection|publisher= Atlantic|location=Penryn|year=1998|isbn=0-906899-91-5}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|editor-last=Garratt|editor-first= Colin|title=Great Railway Photographers: Maurice Earley|publisher=Milepost 92½|location=Newton Harcourt|year=1996|isbn=1-900193-60-4}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|editor-last=Garratt|editor-first= Colin|title=Great Railway Photographers: E. R. Weathersett|publisher=Milepost 92½|location=Newton Harcourt|year=1996|isbn=1-900193-65-5}}</ref><ref name="Harris - photo"> {{cite magazine |last=Harris|first= Nigel|title=The National Railway Museum Photographic Archive |magazine=Steam World|volume=51|pages=6–13|date=September 1991}}</ref>
In 1999/2000 the Museum began to collect recordings of former railway staff for a National Archive of Railway Oral History. It also holds the archive of steam train recordings by [[Peter Handford]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clarke|first1=Andrew|title=Peter Handford|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jan/09/obituaries.mainsection|accessdate=30 January 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|date=9 January 2008}}</ref> In 2009 [[The Forsythe Collection]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Collections of Fiona Forsythe and Robert. N. Forsythe|url=http://www.forsythe.demon.co.uk/collections.htm|publisher=Robert Forsythe|location=Prudhoe|accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref> of travel and transport ephemera was acquired for the collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forsytheonthenrm.blogspot.com/2009/06/nrm-text-of-press-release-regarding.html|title=NRM text of press release regarding the Forsythe Collection issued 16th June 2009|accessdate=18 June 2009}}</ref> Many of the museum's artworks and posters can also be viewed through Search Engine although these are now displayed in a series of temporary exhibitions in the museum's new art gallery which opened in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rogers|first=Emma|title=NRM Art Gallery Opening|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/AboutUs/PressOffice/PressReleases/2011/July/japanfeature.aspx|publisher=National Railway Museum|accessdate=18 July 2012}}</ref>
The Search Engine facility opened in late 2007 and is open from 10:00 to 17:30 Wednesday to Saturday. The archive and library collections can be viewed by anyone without an appointment although the website recommends pre-booking archive materials at least 24 hours in advance. The majority of its collections have been listed on its [http://www.nrm.org.uk/ResearchAndArchive/archiveandlibrarycollections.aspx website] for people to view what materials are available prior to their visit. For those people that cannot visit the museum itself there is a research service offered by the museum called [http://www.nrm.org.uk/ResearchAndArchive/enquiriesandvisiting.aspx Inreach].
==Origins== [[File:Napier Deltic, Alycidon.jpg|thumb|Napier Deltic powered [[British Rail Class 55]] D9009 ''Alycidon'', at the National Railway Museum]] Although there had been amateur attempts to establish a national railway museum from the late 19th century, the National Collection today results from the fusion of two long-running official initiatives. One was led by the State museums sector, evidencing pioneering technology, and the other by the railway industry, in which the key contribution came from the [[North Eastern Railway (UK)|North Eastern Railway]] as successors to the historic [[Stockton and Darlington Railway]].
What became the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] collection was begun in the 1860s by the Patent Office,<ref>{{cite book|last=Liffen|first= John|editor-last=Lewis|editor-first= M. J. T. |title=Early Railways 2|year=2003|publisher=Newcomen Society|location=London|isbn=0-904685-13-6|pages=202–20|chapter=The Patent Office Museum and the beginnings of railway locomotive preservation}}</ref> whose museum included such early relics as ''Puffing Billy'', Stephenson’s ''Rocket'' and ''Agenoria'' (sister locomotive to ''[[Stourbridge Lion]]''), which was outhoused to York at an early date.
Preservation of redundant equipment by the railway companies themselves was a matter of chance. Sometimes relics were stored in company workshops and offices and some were destroyed as circumstances changed. Where put on public display at all the equipment was usually mounted on railway stations in a case or on a plinth. ''Coppernob'' at [[Barrow-in-Furness]], ''Derwent'' and ''Locomotion'' at [[Darlington]] and ''Tiny'' at [[Newton Abbot]] were long-lived examples of this form of display.
The first railway museums were opened at Hamar in [[Norway]] (1896)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/norway/central-norway/hamar/sights/museums-galleries/norwegian-railway-museum|title=Attractions in Hamar, Norway|first=Lonely|last=Planet|date=|website=lonelyplanet.com}}</ref> and [[Nuremberg]] in [[Germany]] (1899). These inspired talk of doing the same in Britain, both in the 1890s and again in 1908,<ref>{{cite book|last=Steel|first= Ernest A. |last2=Steel |first2=Elenora H.|title=The Miniature World of Henry Greenly|publisher=Model & Allied Publications|location=Kings Langley|year=1973|isbn=0-85242-306-3|pages=45–8}}</ref> but this came to nothing at that time. Indeed, two of the [[Great Western Railway]]’s earliest broad-gauge locomotives, ''North Star'' and ''Lord of the Isles'', which had been set aside at [[Swindon Works]], were cut up in 1906 for lack of space and several other relics were similarly lost in subsequent years.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barker|first=Robert|title='Lost' preserved railway rolling stock|journal=Transport History|volume=9|pages=100–9|year=1978}}</ref>
From 1880, J. B. Harper of the North Eastern had been collecting material much of which was exhibited on the occasion of the S.& D.R. centenary in 1925;<ref>{{cite book|author=London & North Eastern Railway|title=Catalogue of the Collection of Railway Relics and Modern Stock at Faverdale, Darlington|publisher=L.N.E.R|year=1925}}</ref> and which then formed the basis of a museum opened at [[York]] by the [[London and North Eastern Railway]] in 1928 under the curatorship of E. M. Bywell.
The smaller exhibits were housed in the old station buildings and the rolling stock and other large exhibits in the former locomotive erecting and repair shops of the old [[York and North Midland Railway]] (demolished after the museum closed).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Household|first= H. G. W.|title=The Railway Museum, London & North Eastern Ry., York|journal=Locomotive|volume=33–4|pages=332–4, 387–9, 49–52|date=August 1927}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Appleby|first= Ken|title=Britain’s Rail Super Centres – York|publisher=[[Ian Allan Publishing|Ian Allan]]|location=Shepperton|year=1993|isbn=0-7110-2072-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Hopkin|first= Dieter|editor-last=Evans|editor-first= A. K. B. |editor2-last= Gough|editor2-first= J. V. |title=The Impact of the Railway on Society in Britain|year=2003|publisher=Ashgate|location=Aldershot|isbn=0-7546-0949-9|pages=243–58|chapter=The North Eastern Railway Museum York – 'the germ of a truly National Railway Museum'}}</ref> Despite this however, the locomotives were displayed on short lengths of track acting as plinths, very much in traditional museum style. It was only when the NRM was formed that Britain acquired a rail-served railway museum where large exhibits could come and go with ease.
The collection was dominated by items from the North Eastern Railway, together with [[Great Northern Railway (Great Britain)|Great Northern Railway]] items. The other three ‘[[Big Four British railway companies|Big Four]]’ railway companies showed little interest in contributing to the LNER’s initiative, though eventually one locomotive representative of each did find its way there: the Great Western's [[GWR 3700 Class 3440 City of Truro|''City of Truro'']], [[London and North Western Railway]] ''Columbine'' and [[London, Brighton and South Coast Railway]] [[LB&SCR B1 Class|B1 Class]] ''Gladstone''.
The GWR assembled a valuable collection of small objects, mounted privately in a long corridor at [[London Paddington station|Paddington station]], and in 1925 it built a replica of ''North Star''. It preserved ''City of Truro''<ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Harris|editor-first= Nigel|title=City of Truro, a locomotive legend|publisher=Silver Link Publishing|location=Carnforth|year=1985|isbn=0-947971-02-5}}</ref> and ''Tiny'' in 1931 and purchased ''Shannon'' for preservation in 1946.
The LMS had its own collection of small objects at [[Euston railway station|Euston]]. It also began to build up a collection of historic locomotives, which included [[Caledonian Railway Single|Caledonian 123]], ''Columbine'', ''Cornwall'', ''Hardwicke'', Highland 103, Midland 118 and ''Pet''. Three others, set aside for preservation at [[Crewe Works]], were scrapped in a change of policy in 1932. The LMS set aside one further locomotive (Midland 158A) before it was overtaken by nationalisation. It also succeeded in preserving a collection of historic royal saloons at [[Wolverton]] and built a replica ''Rocket'', with six replica carriages, for the [[Liverpool & Manchester Railway]] centenary in 1930, and a replica [[Grand Junction Railway]] Travelling Post Office.
The [[Southern Railway (Great Britain)|Southern Railway]] inherited three preserved carriages of the [[Bodmin and Wadebridge Railway]], long displayed at York and at [[London Waterloo railway station|Waterloo station]], but otherwise had no policy of preserving redundant equipment. ''Ryde'' was preserved from 1934 until cut up in 1940; the only other locomotive preserved by the Southern was ''Boxhill'' in 1947. (''Gladstone'' was preserved by the [[Stephenson Locomotive Society]] as a private initiative and much later (in 1959) donated to the [[British Transport Commission]].) [[File:GNR C2 990 'Henry Oakley' at Doncaster Works.JPG|thumb|right|[[Great Northern Railway (Great Britain)|Great Northern Railway]] [[GNR Class C1 (small boiler)|Class C1]] 990 ''Henry Oakley'', first [[4-4-2 (locomotive)|Atlantic]] in Britain, at its birthplace, [[Doncaster Works]] ]]
The [[nationalisation of British Railways]] in 1948 gave the opportunity for a more consolidated approach and a report was produced by the British Transport Commission in 1951.<ref>
{{cite book|title=The Preservation of Relics and Records: report to the British Transport Commission|publisher=British Transport Commission|location=London|year=1951}}</ref>
Amongst other things this recommended a curator be appointed for the Commission’s holdings (John M. Scholes), retention of the York museum, creation of other regional museums (not carried out in the way proposed), a small relics display in the old Great Hall at [[Euston railway station]] (done on a temporary basis) and a large museum of collections elsewhere in London. For the latter, [[Nine Elms railway station|the former station at Nine Elms]] was originally favoured as a site, but what was eventually opened in 1961 was the Museum of British Transport in a former [[bus]] garage in [[Clapham]].<ref> {{cite book|last=Rolt|first= L. T. C.|title=Transport Treasures|publisher=British Transport Commission|location=London|year=1962}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Ellis|first= C. Hamilton|title=Popular Carriage|publisher=British Transport Commission|location=London|year=1954}}</ref> An official list of locomotives for preservation was compiled,<ref> {{cite journal|last=Skeat|first= W. O.|title=The Consultative Panel and the transport museums|journal=Journal of the Stephenson Locomotive Society|volume=42|pages=263–73|year=1966}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Nock|first= O. S.|title=Historical Steam Locomotives|publisher=A. & C. Black|location=London|year=1959}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last= Nock|first= O. S.|title=Steam Locomotive|publisher=British Transport Commission|location=London|year=1955}}</ref> and many were stored in sheds and works throughout the country, others being placed on loan to local authority museums. The [[Swindon Steam Railway Museum|'Steam' Museum]] at [[Swindon]] still displays a large number of items from the National Collection, while the [[Glasgow Museum of Transport]] was also indebted to it, although many of the Scottish relics (including [[North British Railway|NBR]] [[NBR K Class|K 'Glen' Class]] [[4-4-0]] No. 256 ''Glen Douglas'' currently at the [[Bo'ness & Kinneil Railway]]) no longer form part of the National Collection.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/collections/locomotives.asp|title=NRM – Collections – Locomotives|accessdate=5 December 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210184958/http://www.nrm.org.uk/collections/locomotives.asp|archivedate=10 December 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The [[Beeching Report]] recommended that British Rail should stop running museums, and a campaign was led by transport historian [[L. T. C. Rolt]] and others such as the historian [[Jack Simmons (historian)|Jack Simmons]] to create a new museum.<ref> {{cite book|last=Rolt|first= L. T. C.|title=Landscape with figures|publisher=Alan Sutton|location=Stroud|year=1992|isbn=0-86299-998-7|pages=217–21}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography |title=Jack Simmons |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/74629|accessdate=27 April 2012|first=G.H.|last=Martin|date=May 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/74629}} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> Agreement was reached under terms in the Transport Act 1968 for B.R. to provide premises to be occupied by a National Railway Museum which would be a branch of the [[National Museum of Science and Industry]] then under Dame [[Margaret Weston]] and the first English [[national museum]] outside London – a move which was at the time criticised by Londoners.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/the-northerner/2016/may/03/railway-museum-transport-york-london-1969-archive|date=3 May 1969|accessdate=3 May 2016|first=Terry|last=Coleman|newspaper=The Guardian|title=Decision to move museum north angers Londoners}}</ref>
The building provided was the former locomotive [[Railway roundhouse|roundhouse]] at York North (rebuilt in the 1950s), alongside the East Coast Main Line. The old museum and that at Clapham were closed in 1973. A [[Sainsbury's]] [[supermarket]] now stands on the Clapham site. Some items were retained in the capital and formed the basis of the [[London Transport Museum]] in Covent Garden. Some from York were re-located to the [[Darlington Railway Centre and Museum]]. Exhibits from the previous museums at York and Clapham moved to the new site were supplemented by vehicles taken from storage at Preston Park in [[Brighton]] and elsewhere and restored. Creation of the York museum was largely in the hands of its first keeper, [[John Coiley|Dr John Coiley]],<ref> {{cite book|last=Divall|first=Colin|chapter=Coiley, John Arthur (1932–1998)|title=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|chapter-url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/69817|accessdate=14 January 2008}}</ref> his deputy Peter Semmens,<ref> {{cite news|title=Peter Semmens|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 April 2007|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/news/2007/04/03/db0302.xml|accessdate=17 August 2007|location=London}}</ref> [[John Van Riemsdijk]]<ref> {{cite news|last=Hall-Patch|first=Tony|title=John van Riemsdijk: curator who helped set up the National Railway Museum|work=The Guardian|date=27 November 2008|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2008/nov/27/john-van-riemsdijk|accessdate=4 December 2008|location=London}}</ref> of the Science Museum and [[David Jenkinson]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=van Riemsdijk|first= John|title=David Jenkinson|journal=Backtrack|volume=18|year=2004|pages=508–9}}</ref>
==Growth 1975–2000== [[File:NRM line up.jpg|thumb|left|Locomotives arranged around the turntable in the Great Hall]] The museum was opened by [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]] in 1975. The opening coincided with the 150th anniversary celebrations of the opening of the Stockton & Darlington Railway, for which several working exhibits were provided. By comparison with the museum’s predecessors coverage of ordinary [[passenger car (rail)|passenger coach]]es and non-steam motive power was enhanced, but a popular new exhibit was [[Southern Region of British Railways|ex-Southern Railway]] [[SR Merchant Navy Class|Merchant Navy Class]] No. 35029 ''Ellerman Lines'' [[Archaeological section|sectioned]] to show the workings of a steam locomotive. The new museum received over a million visitors in its first year and was favourably received by critics.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cossons|first= Neil|title=The National Railway Museum, York|journal=Museums Journal|volume=76|pages=63–5|year=1976}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Simmons|first= Jack|title=Dandy-Cart to Diesel: the National Railway Museum|publisher=H.M.S.O|location=London|year=1981|isbn=0-11-290299-5 }}</ref>
Significant events of 1979 were the restoration of a train of appropriate vehicles to mark the centenary of on-train catering<ref>{{cite book|title=Centenary Express: a guide to the National Railway Museum Catering Centenary Train|publisher=H.M.S.O|year=1979}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal|last=Jenkinson|first=David|last2=St John-Smith|first2= Emma|title=The National Railway Museum Catering Centenary Train|journal=Yesteryear Transport|volume=3|date=Winter 1980|pages=84–7}}</ref> and an exhibition to mark the centenary of [[railway electric traction]] which drew attention to the museum's important collections in this area.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gibbon|first=R. H.|title=The electric traction exhibits of the National Collection|journal=Friends of the National Railway Museum Newsletter|volume=75|pages=14–18|date=May 1996}}</ref>
Also in 1979 the museum commissioned a working replica of [[Stephenson's Rocket]] for the following year’s [[Liverpool and Manchester Railway]] 150th anniversary.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Satow|first=M. G.|title=Rocket reborn|magazine=Railway Magazine|volume=125|pages=472–4|year=1979}}</ref> This has since represented the museum at events around the world.
Another working replica was added to the collection for the 150th anniversary of establishment of the [[Great Western Railway]] in 1985: that of the {{RailGauge|7ft}} [[Broad Gauge#History|broad gauge]] locomotive [[GWR Iron Duke Class|''Iron Duke'']].
In 1990, The [[Rev. W. Awdry]]'s [[Railway Series]] [[Thomas the Tank Engine]] books were assured a permanent place in the NRM's collection of historical railway books, due to their role in maintaining children's interests in railways. In 1991, Christopher Awdry chose to fictionalise this event in ''[[List of Railway Series Books|Thomas and the Great Railway Show]]'', where Thomas (the most iconic of Awdry's characters) was made an honorary member of the NRM collection by Sir Topham Hatt and the Director of the NRM.
Concerns about the condition of the [[concrete]] roof structure on the main building brought forward major changes to the museum in 1990. To maintain a presence at York, the former York goods depot across Leeman Road, already in use as a museum store (the Peter Allen Building), was configured to display trains as if in a passenger station, and this together with the adjacent South Yard was marketed as ''The Great Railway Show''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Blakemore|first= Michael|title=Great Railway Show at the National Railway Museum, York: souvenir booklet|publisher=National Museum of Science & Industry|year=1990}}</ref> A further selection of exhibits formed the ''National Railway Museum on Tour'' on display for a season in the former [[Swindon Works]].<ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Heap|editor-first= Christine|title=National Railway Museum on Tour – Swindon, 1990|publisher=National Museum of Science & Industry|year=1990}}</ref>
Meanwhile, the main building was completely re-roofed and reconstructed retaining only one of the two original 1954 [[Turntable (railroad)|turntables]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Coiley|first= J. A.|title=York locoshed furore: NRM replies|magazine=Steam Railway|volume=116|date=December 1989|page=76}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Rob|last=Shorland-Ball|title=All Change: New buildings and displays at the National Railway Museum, 1988-1992|journal=National Railway Museum Review|volume=154|date=Winter 2015–16|pages=10–15}}</ref>
It was reopened on 16 April 1992 by [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent]] as the Great Hall giving enhanced opportunities to display large artifacts such as [[railway signals]], a [[Foot Over Bridge|footbridge]] from [[Percy Main Metro station|Percy Main station]] and a segment from the [[Channel Tunnel]].<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Duke of Kent Opens National Railway Museum's Great Hall |magazine=[[The Railway Magazine]] |issue=1094 |date=June 1992 |page=10 }}</ref> The former goods shed display was retained as the Station Hall. [[File:Railway signals.jpg|thumb|[[#Semaphore signals|Semaphore railway signals]] in the Museum’s Great Hall]]
In 1995 the museum joined forces with the [[University of York]] to create an academic research base, the Institute of Railway Studies (and Transport History).<ref>{{cite web|title=Institute of Railway Studies and Transport History|url=http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/irs/|publisher=University of York|accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref> It has also since partnered with [[York College (York)|York College]] to create the Yorkshire Rail Academy to teach vocational skills. The museum has also provided [[engineering apprentice]]ships and participates in partnerships aimed at delivering heritage skills training.<ref> {{cite journal|last=Ashby|first= Helen|title=Teaching old dogs new tricks... and new dogs old tricks?|journal=National Railway Museum Review|volume=120|pages=11–12|date=Summer 2007}}</ref>
In 1996 the Museum Garden was created incorporating a {{RailGauge|7.25in}} [[Rail gauge|gauge]] [[ridable miniature railway]]. A playground was also added.
Continued concern over the condition of the remaining 1950s buildings on the site led to their replacement by ''The Works'' in 1999. This gave several functional areas: the ''Workshop'', for maintenance of rolling stock;<ref>{{cite web|first=David|last=Fowler|title=On track with rail buff|url=https://www.theengineer.co.uk/inspiration/on-track-with-rail-buff/|work=[[The Engineer (magazine)|The Engineer]]|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> the ''Workshop Gallery'', from which the public can look down on this work; a ''Working Railway Gallery'', giving an insight into current and recent operation including a balcony overlooking [[York railway station]] hosting a set of [[video monitor|monitors]] showing live feeds from the monitors at York [[Integrated Electronic Control Centre|IECC]];<ref>{{cite news|title=Network Rail chairman Rick Haythornthwaite opens new signalling attraction at National Railway Museum in York|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/4706338.New_signalling_attraction_opens_at_National_Railway_Museum_in_York/|accessdate=30 January 2016|work=York Press|date=28 October 2009}}</ref> and the ''Warehouse'' which provides an innovative open storage area, which has proved popular with both public and museum professionals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wright|first=David|title=3D|journal=National Railway Museum Review|volume=97|page=22|date=Autumn 2001}}</ref>
==Developments in the 21st century== [[File:National Railway Museum Inclinator.JPG|thumb|upright|Former inclinator between floors]] In order to provide step-free access from the main hall to the Workshop Gallery, the Museum Inclinator was constructed. Besides its primary function, this also served to demonstrate the workings of a [[funicular railway]]. To that end its workings were exposed in the style of a larger open air funicular railway, rather than being concealed in the fabric of the building as is more normal for intramural lifts.<ref name=nrmpgreen> {{cite press release |url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/2006/greenrailways.asp|title=Green Railways|publisher=National Railway Museum|date=23 May 2006|accessdate=4 October 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001115541/http://www.nrm.org.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/2006/greenrailways.asp |archivedate=1 October 2006 }}</ref> Unfortunately, due to lack of spare parts, it ceased working, and with no plans for repair it was removed by August 2013.
2004 saw several major developments at the museum. Several railway anniversaries were celebrated by a major "Railfest".<ref>{{cite book|title=Railfest: official souvenir programme|publisher=Steam Railway|year=2004}}</ref><ref> {{cite book|last=Gwynne|first=Bob|title=Celebrating Rail: the story of Railfest|publisher=Nostalgia Road|location=Kendal|year=2005|isbn=1-903016-56-8}}</ref>
Another took place from 25–30 May 2008 with a Sixties theme. The [[Shildon Locomotion Museum|Locomotion]] museum was opened at [[Shildon]], [[County Durham]] providing undercover collection care facilities for more rail vehicles (particularly freight wagons) from the museum's collection. In addition, the museum had a high-profile campaign, supported by the [[National Heritage Memorial Fund]], to purchase [[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|''Flying Scotsman'']]<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Scott|first=Andrew|title=How we saved the ''Flying Scotsman'' |magazine=Railway Magazine|volume=150|issue=1238|pages=14–19|date=June 2004}}</ref> which arrived at the Museum as the climax of Railfest.
The first stage of a new centre providing easy access to the museum’s Library and Archives, called "Search Engine",<ref>{{cite magazine |editor=Foster, Richard|title=Search Engine: opening the archives of the NRM |magazine=Steam Railway|volume=324|date=13 June 2006}}</ref><ref> {{cite magazine |last=Richards|first=Stephen|title=Changing the face of the National Railway Museum |magazine=Steam Railway|volume=325|date=July 2006|pages=38–41}}</ref> opened at the end of 2007.
From 18 July to 23 August 2008, a popular new venture was the staging by [[York Theatre Royal]] at the Museum of the play of [[E. Nesbit]]'s ''[[The Railway Children]]'', awarded five stars in ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pick of the week: Theatre|work=The Guardian|date=23 August 2008|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/aug/23/northlistings.theatre|accessdate=12 October 2008|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=The Railway Children|journal=National Railway Museum Review|volume=125|pages=14–17|date=Autumn 2008}}</ref> Following this success, it was repeated in 2009, from 23 July to 3 September, and the museum provided locomotives for subsequent performances at [[Waterloo International railway station|Waterloo International station]] and in [[Toronto]].
Major plans under the name "NRM+" were made for refurbishing the Great Hall display, for which a preliminary [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] contribution was announced in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|title=NRM+|url=http://www.lotterygoodcauses.org.uk/project/nrm|website=Lottery Good Causes|accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref> and seeking potential partners for a further outhousing project.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Hopkins|first=Danny|title=You provide the venue and we'll provide the show |magazine=Steam Railway|volume=357|date= 12 December 2008 – 8 January 2009|pages=6–7}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Haigh|first=Phil|title=NRM annex plan revealed |magazine=Steam Railway|volume=365|date=24 July – 20 August 2009|page=38}}</ref>
There are other partnerships for development of the museum estate and the land around it (much owned by Network Rail) as "York Central"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk|title=NRM website|accessdate=14 January 2008}}</ref> but the economic situation during 2009 put these particular plans in abeyance<ref>{{cite magazine|title=York Central plans now in abeyance|magazine=Today's Railways UK|volume=96|date=December 2009|page=71}}</ref> although a similar York Central project was launched by the city council at the beginning of 2016. The NRM+ project was cancelled in April 2011 due to lack of success in assembling the funding package.<ref>{{Cite_journal|url=http://www.museumsassociation.org/museums-journal/news/27042011-nrm-scraps-facelift|title=National Railway Museum scraps plans for £21m facelift|date=27 April 2011|first=Geraldine|last=Kendall|journal=[[Museums Journal]]|publisher=Museums Association|accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref> However, major changes to the displays in the Station Hall began later in 2011.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Work in Progress – Station Hall|journal=National Railway Museum Review|volume=137|date=Autumn 2011|pages=13–16}}</ref>
In 2012, the NRM decided to repatriate temporarily the two [[LNER Class A4|LNER A4 class]] steam locomotives, numbers [[LNER Class A4 4496 Dwight D Eisenhower|60008 ''Dwight D Eisenhower]]'' and [[LNER Class A4 4489 Dominion of Canada|60010 ''Dominion of Canada]]'' from their homes at the National Railroad Museum in Green Bay, Wis. and Exporail in Montreal, Quebec, as part of the '''Mallard'' 75' event in 2013. The two locomotives would be on loan for up to two years, during which time the locomotives would be cosmetically restored, 60008 in BR Brunswick Green (as it appeared in 1963 on withdrawal) and 60010 as LNER 4489 in Garter Blue with its original Canadian Pacific Railway bell (as it appeared in 1939).
On 8 December 2012 it was announced that an annex to the National Railway Museum would be built close to Leicester North station on the [[Great Central Railway (heritage railway)]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-20651102|work=BBC News|title=Great Central Railway plans museum in Leicester|date=8 December 2012}}</ref>
===Funding crisis point=== In June 2013, the ''York Press'' reported that NRM was facing a funding crisis due to a potential 10% annual cut to the Science Museum Group's funding, an estimated real-terms 25% cut following lay-offs and disbandment of projects. The museum was considering scaling down its functions, re-introducing admissions charges or facing complete closure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/10467289.Campaign_launched_to_save_York_s_National_Railway_Museum_from_closure/|title=Campaign launched to save York's National Railway Museum from closure|author=|date=|website=York Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/calendar/update/2013-06-07/york-mp-lobbies-over-future-of-national-railway-museum/|title=York MP lobbies regarding future of railway museum|date=7 June 2013|publisher=ITV|accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref> However, following a campaign by local residents the Chancellor [[George Osborne]] announced a 5% cut in the museum's budget. This prompted Science Museum Group director [[Ian Blatchford]] to announce two weeks later that the museum had been doubly saved — he added that had the 10% cut taken place the Group would have chosen to close the [[National Media Museum]] in [[Bradford]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/savemuseum/10521833.Bradford_s_National_Media_Museum_saved___that_s_official|title=Media Museum Threat|accessdate=18 January 2014}}</ref>
==Policies== [[File:York Wheel.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[Yorkshire Wheel]], sited from 2006 to 2008 at the NRM, was one of the museum's fund raising initiatives]] Criticisms of the museum which have been raised include claims that it has devoted insufficient attention to modern traction;<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Dunn|first= Pip|title=The NRM on the spot|magazine=Railways Illustrated|volume=5|issue=6|pages=30–2|date=June 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|last=Smith|first=Ian R.|title=Bring them in from the cold!|magazine=Heritage Railway|volume=92|pages=68–71|date=December 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|last=Dunn|first=Pip|title=Museum peace|magazine=Railways Illustrated|pages=28–30|date=October 2009}}</ref> that it was neglecting scholarship in favour of commercialism;<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jenkinson|first=David|title=Quo vadis, NRM?|journal=Backtrack|volume=3|page=99|year=1989}}</ref> or that its photographic collections constitute a "black hole".<ref name="Harris - photo" /> The museum's response is that these criticisms do not always take into account the financial constraints under which the museum operates:<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Courtney|first=Geoff|title=NRM is 'poor relation' of Britain's state museums|magazine=Heritage Railway|volume=92|page=6|date=December 2006}}</ref> its Grant in Aid from the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] amounts to £6.50 per visitor which delivers less overall income than for comparable London museums. For some of its funding the museum depends on money-making events such as the [[Yorkshire Wheel]], which operated at the museum from 2006 to 2008 and visits from [[Thomas the Tank Engine]] as chronicled in ''[[List of Railway Series Books#Thomas and the Great Railway Show|Thomas and the Great Railway Show]]''. The museum has also suffered a few thefts of objects.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Courtney|first= Geoff|title=Four more thefts from NRM |magazine=Heritage Railway|volume=96|page=5|date=April 2007}}</ref>
The museum can be allocated material from the railway industry by the [[Railway Heritage Committee]]. Because of the diversity of material falling potentially within the museum's collection policy and the problems of caring for it, decisions on acquisition of new items for the collection can be difficult.<ref>{{cite book|last=Heap|first= Christine J.|editor-last=Shorland-Ball|editor-first=Rob|title=Common Roots – Separate Branches: railway history and preservation|year=1994|publisher=Science Museum|location=London|isbn=0-901805-77-7|pages=153–5|chapter=The National Railway Museum, York}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Ashby|first=Helen|last2=Bartholomew|first2= Ed|last3=Rees|first3=Jim|title=Electric Multiple Units in the National Collection|journal=National Railway Museum Review|volume=118|pages=13–14|date=Winter 2006–07}}</ref> Previously the museum has treated rolling stock as if it were effectively still in railway service and capable of undergoing repeated heavy repairs and restoration. Since being preserved many of the museum's locomotives have operated on the main line, [[heritage railway]]s or at the museum.<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Ian R.|title=Steam Alive: locomotives of the National Railway Collection in steam|publisher=FNRM|location=York|year=1993|isbn=0-9522396-0-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Blakemore|first=Michael|last2=Mosley|first2=David|title=Great British Locomotives: National Railway Museum locomotives in action|publisher=[[Ian Allan Publishing|Ian Allan]]|location=Shepperton|year=1997|isbn=0-7110-2400-6}}</ref> More recently, there have been moves to less interventionist forms of conservation in some cases leading to some exhibits becoming non-operational.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hopkin|first=Dieter|editor-last=Shorland-Ball|editor-first=Rob|title=Common Roots – Separate Branches: railway history and preservation|year=1994|publisher=Science Museum|location=London|isbn=0-901805-77-7|pages=215–21|chapter=A commentary on restoration, conservation and the National Railway Museum collection}}</ref>
The Museum's management of the protracted overhaul of [[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|LNER Class A3 4472 ''Flying Scotsman'']] was heavily criticised in an internally commissioned report in 2012.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Flying Scotsman debacle|magazine=The Railway Magazine|volume=158|issue=1340|date=December 2012|page=8}}</ref>
Since 1977, the Friends of the National Railway Museum have been in existence as a group to give financial and other support to the museum, such as financing the original restoration to steam of ''Duchess of Hamilton''.
The 1990 "Great Railway Show" won the Museum of the Year award and in 2001 the museum gained the [[European Museum of the Year Award]]. It has also won White Rose awards from the Yorkshire Tourist Board, and in recognition of the several major developments in 2004 was given the [[Heritage Railway Association]]'s Peter Manisty Award.<ref>{{cite news|title=Museum receives award for its efforts|work=Northern Echo|date=1 November 2004|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/6973204.Museum_receives_award_for_its_efforts/|accessdate=21 September 2007}}</ref>
==Online presence== The National Railway Museum website offers a facility for visitors to plan their visit to the museum in advance. The museum also has a policy of improving access to its collections via its website. It has uploaded some of the recordings from the National Archive of Railway History to its website.<ref>{{cite web|title=NRM Railway Voices|work=National Railway Museum|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/RailwayStories/railwayvoices.aspx|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> It has also created an [[App Store (iOS)|iPhone App]] in association with [[East Coast (train operating company)|East Coast]] that allows people travelling between London and Edinburgh on the [[East Coast Main Line]] through York to view objects from the collection in connection with locations on the route.<ref>{{cite web|title=NRM iPhone App|work=National Railway Museum|url=http://timeline.nrm.org.uk/|accessdate=1 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121204082054/http://timeline.nrm.org.uk/|archivedate=4 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The museum's archives and library service Search Engine is increasingly making its collection accessible online by providing catalogues and lists for researchers to search before visiting and adding low resolution copies of its drawing online.<ref>{{cite web|title=NRM collections lists|work=National Railway Museum|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/ResearchAndArchive/archiveandlibrarycollections.aspx/|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> The library collection can be searched through the [[University of York]] library catalogue.<ref>{{cite web|title=University of York Library Catalogue|work=University of York|url=http://libcatalogue.york.ac.uk/F/?func=find-b-0&local_base=nrm/|accessdate=1 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121223135529/http://libcatalogue.york.ac.uk/F/?func=find-b-0&local_base=nrm/|archivedate=23 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> All of the museum's rolling stock and a large amount of other material has also been added to the website<ref>{{cite web|title=NRM Collections|work=National Railway Museum|url=http://www.nrm.org.uk/OurCollection.aspx|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
The National Railway Museum also has a presence on a number of other websites. Copies of many of its posters, photographs and artworks can be ordered through the Science and Society Picture Library.<ref>{{cite web|title=SSPL Prints|work=Science and Society Picture Library|url=http://www.ssplprints.com/|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> The National Railway Museum has a presence on the [[National Preservation]] forums. Members and Readers are able to talk and comment directly to members of the staff. Providing both feedback and constructive criticism, a valuable source of information for the museum. Members of staff can usually answer questions when they are not busy and are part of the National Railway Museum group.<ref>{{cite web|title=Forum: National Railway Museum |work=National-Preservation.com |url=http://railways.national-preservation.com/forumdisplay.php/53-National-Railway-Museum |accessdate=4 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003040017/http://railways.national-preservation.com/forumdisplay.php/53-National-Railway-Museum |archivedate=3 October 2011 }}</ref> National Railway Museum staff also publish a blog via [[WordPress.com]] where staff write stories about events behind the scenes in the museum such as conservation work or preparation for major events.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Railway Museum Blog|work=National Railway Museum|url=http://nationalrailwaymuseum.wordpress.com/|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
==Locomotives== {{Main|List of rolling stock items in the UK National Collection}} These are a few of the Museum's locomotives (listed by operational state, and then by date the design was introduced). ;Operational steam locomotives *[[LSWR N15 Class|SR N15 Class]] 4–6–0 No. [[LSWR N15 Class 30777 Sir Lamiel|30777 ''Sir Lamiel'']]. Currently kept at the [[Great Central Railway (preserved)|Great Central Railway]] where it is operational and worked on the national network until 2013. Boiler certification expires in 2016. *[[SR Schools class]] 4–4–0 No. 925 ''Cheltenham''. Currently working on the [[Watercress Line|Mid Hants Railway]]. Boiler certification expires in 2022. *[[BR Standard Class 7|British Railways Standard Class 7 "Britannia"]] 4–6–2 [[BR standard class 7 70013 Oliver Cromwell|70013 ''Oliver Cromwell'']]. Overhauled at the Great Central Railway (Loughborough) between 2004-2008. Currently based at Loughborough when not working on the National Network. Boiler Certificate expired in August 2015. Recently returned to traffic. *[[LNER Class A1/A3]] 4–6–2 [[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|60103 ''Flying Scotsman'']]. Overhaul started in 2006 by the NRM. After an external review the restoration was taken over by [[Riley and Son]] and completed in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.heritagerailway.co.uk/news/flying-scotsman-restoration-restarts-after-contract-signed |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925120302/http://www.heritagerailway.co.uk/news/flying-scotsman-restoration-restarts-after-contract-signed |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 September 2015 |title=Flying Scotsman restoration restarts after contract signed |date=30 October 2013 |publisher=Heritage Railway Magazine }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rail.co.uk/rail-news/2012/flying-scotsman/ |title=Flying Scotsman – ‘What Went Wrong’ |date=6 November 2012 |publisher=Rail Magazine}}</ref> *[[Grant, Ritchie and Company]] 0-4-0ST no 272. Visiting from the [[Ribble Steam Railway]] for the Christmas period and early 2017. Arrived by road from Preston on 15 December 2016.
;Steam locomotives under overhaul/stored *[[SR Lord Nelson Class]] 4–6–0 No. 850 ''Lord Nelson''. Currently working on the Mid Hants Railway. Boiler certification expired in 2016. *[[GCR Class 8K|Great Central Railway O4 Class]] 2–8–0 No. 63601. Currently on the Great Central Railway. Withdrawn in 2012 for overhaul.
;Steam locomotives on static display *[[Stephenson's Rocket]] 0–2–2 ''Rocket''. Two replicas are in the York collection, one built for operation (rebuilt 2009–10) and one sectioned. (The original is with the parent body, the Science Museum in London.) *[[NER 66 Aerolite|NER No. 66 ''Aerolite'']]. On static display in York since 1934. *[[GWR 4000 Class]] 4–6–0 [[GWR 4000 Class 4003 Lode Star|4003 ''Lode Star'']]. Returned to the NRM in November 2015 from the [[Museum of the Great Western Railway]], [[Swindon]] as part of an exchange of locomotives in preparation for Swindon 175 in 2016.<ref name="Back Home">{{cite magazine|title=Back home! Swindon legends go back on display|magazine=The Railway Magazine|date=2 December 2015|volume=161|issue=1377|page=9|publisher=[[Mortons Media Group]]|location=Horncastle, Lincolnshire|issn=0033-8923}}</ref> *[[LMS Stanier Class 5 4-6-0]] [[LMS Stanier Class 5 4-6-0 5000|5000]]. On static display. *[[LNWR G Class]] ("Super D") 0–8–0 No. 49395. In service and usually on loan to other railways; when it is not touring it is stabled either at York or Crewe. Currently at Locomotion, Shildon. *[[LNER Class V2]] 2–6–2 [[LNER Class V2 4771 Green Arrow|4771/60800 ''Green Arrow'']]. After many years of being a popular operation engine, her boiler certificate was due to expire Spring 2008, but failed beforehand on the North Yorkshire Moors Railway. In need of extensive repairs to her one-piece three cylinder block, she is unlikely to steam again in the near future due to cost and NRM policy. Returned to York after a two-year loan to Locomotion at Shildon. *[[LNER Class A4]] 4–6–2 [[LNER Class A4 4468 Mallard|4468 ''Mallard'']]. Restored to steam for a time from 1986; now on static display. Unlikely to run again due to exhibit popularity and the fact that all the other A4s in the UK have been restored to working order. *[[SR Class Q1]] 0–6–0 No. C1. On static display. However it is possible it will return to the [[Bluebell Railway]], where it was based for many years, to be returned to service. *[[BR standard class 9F]] 2–10–0 [[BR standard class 9F 92220 Evening Star|92220 ''Evening Star'']], the last steam locomotive built for [[British Rail]]ways. On static display and not expected to return to working order due to class being barred from running on the national network. Returned to York in 2010 after a two-year loan to the [[Museum of the Great Western Railway]], [[Swindon]]. *[[LMS Princess Coronation Class]] 4–6–2 [[LMS Princess Coronation Class 6229 Duchess of Hamilton|6229 ''Duchess of Hamilton'']]. Returned to the NRM in 2009 after being re-streamlined, it was at first displayed in an exhibit, ''Streamlined: Styling an era''.
;Steam locomotives located away from York
*[[GWR 3700 Class]] 4–4–0 [[GWR 3700 Class no. 3440 "City of Truro"|3440 ''City of Truro'']]. Loaned to the Museum of the Great Western Railway in November 2015 as part of an exchange of locomotives in preparation for Swindon 175 in 2016.<ref name="Back Home"/> *[[GWR 6000 Class]] 4–6–0 [[GWR 6000 Class 6000 King George V|6000 ''King George V'']]. Loaned to the Museum of the Great Western Railway in November 2015 as part of an exchange of locomotives in preparation for Swindon 175 in 2016.<ref name="Back Home"/> *[[Robert Stephenson and Hawthorns]] 0-4-0ST No. 15 ''Eustace Forth''. Outstationed at Locomotion, Shildon to help maintain a working locomotive presence there.

{{Infobox military person |image =NilsJorgenFuglesangVF.jpg |caption = |name=Nils Jørgen Fuglesang |birth_date={{Birth date|1918|10|07|df=yes}} |death_date={{Death date and age|1944|3|29|1921|11|28|df=yes}} |placeofburial= Poznan Old Garrison Cemetery, [[Poland]] |birth_place=[[Hidra (island)|Hidra]], [[Flekkefjord]], [[Norway]] |death_place= Rote Hahn near [[Kiel]], [[Germany]] |nickname= |birth_name= |allegiance={{flag|Norway}} |branch= |serviceyears=1941–1944 |rank=[[Lieutenant]], [[Pilot Officer]] |servicenumber=742 |unit=[[No. 332 Squadron RAF]] |commands= |battles=[[World War II]] *[[Western Front (World War II)|Channel Front]] ([[POW]]) |battles_label= |awards=[[King Haakon VII Freedom Medal]], [[Mentioned in Despatches]] {{plainlist| }} |relations= }} ''' Nils Jørgen Fuglesang ''' (7 October 1918 – 29 March 1944), was a Norwegian [[Supermarine Spitfire]] pilot who was taken prisoner during the [[Second World War]]. He is notable for the part he took in the 'Great Escape' from [[Stalag Luft III]] in March 1944 and as one of the men re-captured and subsequently shot by the ''[[Gestapo]]''.
==Pre-war life== Fuglesang was born at [[Rasvåg]] in [[Hidra (island)|Hidra]], near [[Flekkefjord]], [[Norway]] the son of a customs official<ref name="Vance 176">Vance (2000), p.176</ref> he was raised and educated in [[Florø]]. German prisoner of war records confirm his residency in Florø<ref name="Andrews photo pg">Andrews (1976), photo page – German records</ref> but do not give any details of his date and place of birth. From September 1935 Fuglesang received three years education in economics at the French Lycee Pierre Corneille in [[Rouen]]<ref>[http://lgcorneille-lyc.spip.ac-rouen.fr/IMG/pdf/Nils_Jorgen_FUGLESANG.pdf LG Corneille website – Nils Fuglesang]</ref> before studying at the Bergen Commercial College. He was working as an apprentice with an [[Oslo]] shipping company when the war began. Following the [[Operation Weserübung|German invasion]] in April 1940 and the [[Norwegian campaign|ensuing battles]] the country [[German occupation of Norway|was occupied]]. Fuglesang decided to escape from Norway to get to Great Britain and join the [[Norwegian Armed Forces in exile]]. Sea traffic was closely monitored by the Germans who were aware of significant numbers of young Norwegians wishing to continue the fight from England, frequent checks and searches were made and penalties harsh for anybody caught. On 12 March 1941 he escaped from Kyammen to [[Shetland]] aboard the boat ''Heimfjell'' with 11 others.
==War service== Fuglesang enlisted in the [[Norwegian Army Air Service]] with service number 742 and sailed in May to Canada to train at [[Little Norway]], the [[Norwegian Armed Forces in exile|exiled Norwegian forces]] camp at [[Toronto Island Airport]]. He completed basic training and learned more English language then completing flight training. He was awarded his [[aircrew brevet]] pilots wings and promoted [[sergeant]] towards the end of 1941.<ref name="Vance 176" /> His instructors recommended that had the aptitude to become a fighter pilot during which he was promoted to [[lieutenant]]. After further training Fuglesang sailed for England where he joined Operational Training Unit and began to fly [[Supermarine Spitfire]] aircraft. On 9 June 1942 he joined [[No. 332 Squadron RAF]]<ref name="Vance 176" /><ref>Ulstein (1979)</ref> a squadron manned by Norwegian personnel flying [[Supermarine Spitfire]].<ref>[http://www.cieldegloire.com/002n_fuglesang_n_j.php Ciel de Gloire website – Nils Guglesang]</ref> at [[RAF North Weald]] flying operationally with the fighter wing commanded by [[wing commander (rank)|wing commander]] [[Don Finlay]] which operated from that base. He flew on fighter sweep and bomber escort missions over the [[English Channel]] to occupied France and the Netherlands. In action on 20 January 1943 he attacked a German [[Fw 190]] fighter over the French coast, this was assessed as probably destroyed.<ref>[http://wingstovictory.nl/database/pdf/245-story.pdf Wings to Victory – Nils Fuglesang]</ref> His reputation as a reliable and steady pilot resulted in him being awarded the Norwegian [[King Haakon VII Freedom Medal]] and a promotion to [[pilot officer]] in March 1943.<ref name="Vance 176" />
==Prisoner of war== [[File:Model Stalag Luft III.jpg|thumb|right|305px|Model of Stalag Luft III prison camp.]] At 1905 hours on 2 May 1943 Nils Jørgen Fuglesang was flying [[Supermarine Spitfire]] Mark IX (serial number “BS540” squadron codes “AH-E”) on a Ramrod mission with [[North Weald]] wing over south west Holland.<ref name="Franks 95">Franks (1998), p.95</ref><ref>[http://wingstovictory.nl/database/pdf/245-story.pdf Wings to Victory Website – Nils Fuglesang]</ref> His squadron were in action with [[Luftwaffe]] [[Focke Wulf]] [[Fw 190]] fighters and as wingman he stuck to the tail of his lead pilot until a burst of 20mm cannon fire intended for the lead aircraft hit his own aircraft.<ref>National Archives, London. Operations Record Book, 332 Squadron. Appendix 02/05/1943</ref> Fuglesang crash landed in Zeeland, the SW part of Holland and was taken prisoner by German infantrymen training close by.<ref name="Vance 176" /><ref>[http://www.rafcommands.com/archive/11548.php RAF Commands – Nils Fuglesang]</ref> Photograph of his crashed aircraft is in Franks book.<ref name="Franks 95" /> He became prisoner of war No. 1264<ref name="Andrews photo pg" /> held at [[Stalag Luft III]] in the province of Lower Silesia near the town of [[Sagan, Germany|Sagan]] (now [[Żagań]] in [[Poland]]).
=='Great Escape'== Fuglesang was an enthusiastic member of the tunneling crew participating in regular shifts to lengthen and shore up the tunnel, he and fellow Norwegian [[Halldor Espelid]] were near the front of the list of men escaping and they had cleared the tunnel exit by 2230 hours.<ref name="Andrews 55">Andrews (1976), p.55</ref> So he was one of the 76 men who escaped the prison camp on the night of 24–25 March 1944 in the escape now famous as "[[Stalag Luft III|the Great Escape]]". He teamed up with fellow Free Norwegian [[Halldor Espelid]], [[James Catanach]] an Australian who was fluent in German and spoke Norwegian and the New Zealander of Danish ancestry [[Arnold George Christensen]] in a group heading for Denmark and possibly ultimately neutral Sweden. Fuglesang and his team reached Berlin<ref name="Andrews 55" /> as they were seen there by other escapers before they changed trains to Hamburg which they also reached successfully only to be caught on the next leg of their rail journey from Hamburg to the naval town of Flensburg on the Danish border. Nearing the Danish border on 26 March 1944 a suspicious policemen insisted on carefully examining their papers and checking their briefcases which contained newspapers and escape rations. Close inspection of their clothing revealed they were wearing altered greatcoats.<ref>[http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4605/history/story01.htm Australian Defence Website – Fuglesang and Catanach] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120191115/http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4605/history/story01.htm |date=2007-11-20 }}</ref> Although the four escapees had split up to pretend to be travelling individually they were all in the same railway carriage, more policemen arrived and closely examined every passenger, soon arresting all four suspects. An alternative version states that the two Norwegians were arrested on the Marienhelzungsweg and Catanach and Christensen on the Helm.<ref>Read (2012), p.266</ref> The escapers were taken to Flensburg prison.<ref name="Walker">Walker (2015)</ref> The four men were handed over to the Kiel Gestapo and after interrogation were told that they would be taken by road back to prison camp.<ref>[http://lgcorneille-lyc.spip.ac-rouen.fr/IMG/pdf/Nils_Jorgen_FUGLESANG.pdf LG Corneille website – photos of Fuglesang and colleagues after recapture]</ref>
On 29 March 1944 two black sedan cars arrived, [[James Catanach]] was taken in the first car with three Gestapo agents including SS-Sturmbannfuhrer Johannes Post a senior officer based there. Post had his driver stop the car in the countryside outside Kiel about 1630 hours and called [[James Catanach]] out into a field where he promptly shot him.<ref>Read (2012), p.23-35</ref><ref>Andrews (1976), p.169-172</ref> The second car drew up in the same place shortly afterwards and Post told his agents to get the hand-cuffed [[Arnold George Christensen]], [[Halldor Espelid]] and Nils Fuglesang out, stating that they should take a break before their long drive. As the airmen walked into the field they almost stumbled over Catanach’s body as they were also shot.<ref>Andrews (1976), p.172-173 and p.177-178</ref><ref name="Walker" /><ref>Andrews (1976) p.196</ref><ref>Read (2012), p.288</ref><ref name="Burgess">Burgess (1990), p.271</ref><ref>[http://www.pegasusarchive.org/pow/cSL_3_Fifty.htm Pegasus Archive - 50 murdered escapers]</ref> The four men were cremated at [[Kiel]] under [[Gestapo]] supervision.
Fuglesang was one of the 50 escapers who had been listed by SS-Gruppenfuhrer [[Arthur Nebe]] to be killed<ref>Andrews (1976), p.34</ref><ref>Read (2012), p.304</ref><ref name="Andrews photo pg" /> so was amongst the unfortunate [[Stalag Luft III murders|executed and murdered]] by the ''Gestapo''.<ref>Feast (2015), p.140</ref><ref name="Burgess" /><ref>Andrews (1976), p.205</ref> Originally his remains were buried at Sagan, but his cremation urn was removed to Kirkehavn [[Hidra (island)|Hidra]] near [[Flekkefjord]], Norway for his family.<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/26754337 N J Fuglesang grave]</ref><ref>Walton (2014), p422</ref><ref>[http://wingstovictory.nl/database/pdf/245-story.pdf Wings to Victory- Nils Fuglesang]</ref>
The Norwegians Nils Fuglesang and [[Halldor Espelid]] were on the list of officers named in the British press on 20 May 1944 as having been killed.<ref>Western Morning News, Dundee Courier, Yorkshire Post, 20/05/1944</ref>
[[File:The50Memorial.jpg|thumb|Memorial to "The Fifty" down the road toward Żagań (Espelid at left)]]
==Awards== *[[King Haakon VII Freedom Medal]] awarded March 1943<ref name="Vance 176" /> for significant service to Norway during the Second World War. *[[Mention in Despatches]] by the [[Royal Air Force]] for his actions in captivity, as none of the other relevant decorations then available could be awarded posthumously. It was not published in the supplement to the ''London Gazette'' on 8 June 1944 when the British and Commonwealth personnel were honoured for fear of reprisals against his family in German occupied Norway.
==Other victims== {{main|Stalag Luft III murders}}
The ''Gestapo'' executed a group of 50 of the recaptured prisoners representing almost all of the nationalities involved in the escape. Post-war investigations saw a number of those guilty of the murders tracked down, arrested and tried for their crimes.<ref>Read (2012), p.295</ref><ref>Vance (2000), p.310</ref><ref>Andrews (1976), p.188 and 199</ref>
{|class="wikitable" align="right" |Nationalities of the 50 executed |- |{{Flagicon|UK}} 21 British |- |{{Flagicon|Canada|1921}} 6 Canadian |- |{{flagicon|Poland}} 6 Polish |- |{{flagicon|Australia}} 5 Australian |- |{{flagicon|South Africa|1928}} 3 South African |- |{{flagicon|New Zealand}} 2 New Zealanders |- |{{flagicon|Norway}} 2 Norwegian |- |{{flagicon|Belgium}} 1 Belgian |- |{{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} 1 Czechoslovak |- |{{flagicon|France}} 1 Frenchman |- |{{flagicon|Greece|old}} 1 Greek |- |{{flagicon|Lithuania}} [[Romualdas Marcinkus|1 Lithuanian]] |}
