{{Other uses|Pig War (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = Pig War |image = PigWar-boundaries.png |image_size = 300px |caption =
Proposed boundaries:
{{Legend-line|blue solid 2px|Through [[Haro Strait]], favored by the US}} {{Legend-line|red solid 2px|Through [[Rosario Strait]], favored by Britain}} {{Legend-line|lime solid 2px|Through San Juan Channel, compromise proposal}} The lines are as shown on maps of the time. The modern boundary follows straight line segments and roughly follows the blue line. The modern eastern boundary of [[San Juan County, Washington|San Juan County]] roughly follows the red line. |date = June 15 – October 1859 (troops stationed on [[San Juan Island]] until 1874) |place = [[San Juan Islands]] |result = [[Bloodless war]] – San Juan Islands awarded to the United States following third-party arbitration. |combatant1 = {{flag|United States|1858}} *{{flagdeco|United States|1858}} [[Washington Territory]] |combatant2 = {{flag|United Kingdom}} *{{flagdeco|United Kingdom}} [[Colony of Vancouver Island]] |commander1 = Colonel [[Silas Casey]], Captain [[George Pickett]] |commander2 = Rear Admiral [[Robert Lambert Baynes|R. L. Baynes]] |strength1 = 461 combatants, 14 cannon |strength2 = 2,140 combatants; 5 warships mounting 70 cannon }} {{Campaignbox Canada-US}} [[File:Vancouver1798map-SanJuan-Gulf.png|thumb|Vancouver's 1798 map, showing some confusion in the vicinity of southeastern Vancouver Island, the Gulf Islands, and Haro Strait]] The '''Pig War''' was a confrontation in 1859 between the United States and [[United Kingdom]] over the [[Canada–United States border|British–U.S. border]] in the [[San Juan Islands]], between [[Vancouver Island]] and the mainland. The Pig War, so called because it was triggered by the shooting of a [[pig]], is also called the '''Pig Episode''', the '''Pig and Potato War''', the '''San Juan Boundary Dispute''' or the '''Northwestern Boundary Dispute'''. With no shots exchanged and no human casualties, this dispute was a [[bloodless war|bloodless conflict]]. ==Background== The [[Oregon Treaty]] of June 15, 1846, resolved the [[Oregon boundary dispute]] by dividing the [[Oregon Country]]/[[Columbia District]] between the United States and Britain "along the [[49th parallel north|forty-ninth parallel]] of north latitude to the middle of the channel which separates the continent from [[Vancouver Island]], and thence southerly through the middle of the said channel, and of the [[Strait of Juan de Fuca]], to the [[Pacific Ocean]]."[[s:Oregon Treaty|Oregon Treaty]] from Wikisource. Visited October 16, 2006. However, there are actually two straits that could be called the middle of the channel: [[Haro Strait]], along the west side of the [[San Juan Islands]]; and [[Rosario Strait]], along the east side.{{cite web |url=http://www.wahmee.com/pigwar.html |title=The Pig War of San Juan Island |last=Matthews |first=Todd |work=The Tablet |publisher=www.wahmee.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709060607/http://www.wahmee.com/pigwar.html |archivedate=2008-07-09 |accessdate=2012-09-07 }} In 1846, there was still some uncertainty about the geography of the region. The most commonly available maps were those of [[George Vancouver]], published in 1798, and of [[Charles Wilkes]], published in 1845. In both cases the maps are unclear in the vicinity of the southeastern coast of Vancouver Island and the [[Gulf Islands]]. As a result, Haro Strait is not fully clear either.{{cite book |last= Hayes |first= Derek |title= Historical Atlas of the Pacific Northwest: Maps of exploration and Discovery |year= 1999 |publisher= Sasquatch Books |isbn= 1-57061-215-3 |pages= 171–174}} In 1856, the US and Britain set up a Boundary Commission to resolve a number of issues regarding the international boundary, including the water boundary from the Strait of Georgia to the Strait of Juan de Fuca. The British appointed [[James Charles Prevost]] First Commissioner, [[George Henry Richards]] Second Commissioner, and William A. G. Young Secretary. The US appointed Archibald Campbell First Commissioner,{{cite web|title=The International Boundary Commission first meets on June 27, 1857|url=http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&file_id=9328|work=HistoryLink.org|publisher=Online Encyclopedia of Washington State History|accessdate=19 July 2013|author=Phil Dougherty|page=9328|date=28 February 2010}} [[John Parke]] Second Commissioner, and William J. Warren Secretary. On June 27, 1857, the American and British commissioners met for the first time on board the British ship [[HMS Satellite (1855)|HMS ''Satellite'']], anchored in [[Esquimalt Harbour]]. The two sides met several more times in 1857 in [[Esquimalt Harbour]] and [[Nanaimo]] Harbour, and corresponded by letter between meetings. The water boundary was discussed from October to December. From the start, Prevost maintained that Rosario Strait was required by the treaty's wording and was intended by the treaty framers, while Campbell had the same opinion for Haro Strait. Prevost held that the channel specified in the treaty must have three key qualities: # it must separate the continent from Vancouver Island, # it must carry the boundary in a southerly direction, and # it must be navigable. Only Rosario fulfilled these requirements, he wrote. Campbell countered that the expression "southerly", in the treaty, was to be understood in a general sense, that Rosario Strait did not separate the continent from Vancouver Island, but the San Juan Islands from [[Lummi Island]], [[Cypress Island]], [[Fidalgo Island]], and others, and that navigability was not germane to the issue, but even if it was, Haro Strait was the wider and more direct passage. Finally he challenged Prevost to produce any evidence showing that the treaty framers had intended Rosario Strait. Prevost responded to the challenge by referring to American maps showing the boundary running through Rosario Strait, included one by [[John C. Frémont]], produced for and published by the US government, and another by John B. Preston, Surveyor-General of Oregon in 1852. To the other points, Prevost repeated his statements about Rosario Strait's navigability—the channels between Lummi, Cypress, and Fidalgo islands not being navigable—and that a line through Rosario would be southerly, while one through Haro would have to be drawn westerly. The two continued to discuss the issue into December 1857, until it was clear what each side's argument was and that neither would be convinced of the other. Prevost made a final offer at the sixth meeting, December 3. He suggested a compromise line through San Juan Channel, which would give the US all the main islands except San Juan Island. This offer was rejected and the commission adjourned, agreeing to report back to their respective governments. Thus ambiguity over the water boundary remained.{{cite book|last1=Scholefield|first1=Ethelbert Olaf Stuart|last2=Howay|first2=Frederic William|authorlink2=Frederic William Howay|title=British Columbia from the earliest times to the present. Vol. 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vGdJtwAACAAJ|accessdate=22 June 2011|year=1914|publisher=The S.J. Clarke publishing company|oclc= 697901687|pages=303–306}} Because of this ambiguity, both the United States and Britain claimed [[sovereignty]] over the San Juan Islands.{{cite web | url=http://www.nps.gov/archive/sajh/Pig_War_new.htm | title=The Pig War | publisher=National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110072744/http://www.nps.gov/archive/sajh/Pig_War_new.htm | archivedate=2007-01-10 | accessdate=2012-09-07}} During this period of disputed sovereignty, Britain's [[Hudson's Bay Company]] established operations on San Juan and turned the island into a sheep ranch. Meanwhile, by mid-1859, twenty-five to twenty-nine American settlers had arrived.[http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3620632 ''British Columbia: From the earliest times to the present, Vol II''] by E.O.S. Scholefield and F.W. Howay San Juan Island held significance not for its size, but as a military strategic point. While the British held [[Fort Victoria (British Columbia)|Fort Victoria]] on Vancouver Island to the west, overlooking the Strait of Juan de Fuca, the entry point to Haro Strait, leading to the Strait of Georgia, the nation that held the San Juan Islands would be able to dominate all the straits connecting the Strait of Juan de Fuca with the Strait of Georgia.{{Citation needed|reason=While it's fairly obvious that the islands held strategic value, it would be nice to have a source to back up this paragraph|date=June 2011}} ==Pig killed== On June 15, 1859, exactly thirteen years after the adoption of the Oregon Treaty, the ambiguity led to direct conflict. Lyman Cutlar, an American farmer who had moved onto [[San Juan Island]] claiming rights to live there under the [[Donation Land Claim Act]], found a [[Large Black (pig)|large black pig]] rooting in his garden.{{cite news | first=Chuck | last=Woodbury | title=How One Pig Could Have Changed American History | url=http://www.outwestnewspaper.com/pigwars.html | work=Out West #15 | publisher=Out West Newspaper | year=2000 | accessdate=2006-10-16}} He had found the pig eating his [[tuber]]s. This was not the first occurrence. Cutlar was so upset that he took aim and shot the pig, killing it. It turned out that the pig was owned by an Irishman, Charles Griffin, who was employed by the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] to run the sheep ranch. He also owned several pigs that he allowed to roam freely. The two had lived in peace until this incident. Cutlar offered $10 to Griffin to compensate for the pig, but Griffin was unsatisfied with this offer and demanded $100. Following this reply, Cutlar believed he should not have to pay for the pig because the pig had been trespassing on his land. (A probably apocryphal story claims Cutlar said to Griffin, "It was eating my potatoes." Griffin replied, "It is up to you to keep your potatoes out of my pig.") When British authorities threatened to arrest Cutlar, American settlers called for [[military]] protection. ==Military escalation== [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[William S. Harney]], commanding the [[Department of Oregon]], initially dispatched 66 American soldiers of the [[9th Infantry Regiment (United States)|9th Infantry]] under the command of [[Captain (United States)#Captain .28Ground and Air Forces.29|Captain]] [[George Pickett]] to San Juan Island with orders to prevent the British from landing. Concerned that a squatter population of Americans would begin to occupy San Juan Island if the Americans were not kept in check, the British sent three [[warship]]s under the command of [[Captain (Royal Navy)|Captain]] [[Geoffrey Thomas Phipps Hornby|Geoffrey Hornby]] to counter the Americans. Pickett was famously quoted as saying defiantly, "We'll make a [[Battle of Bunker Hill|Bunker Hill]] of it," placing him in the national limelight.{{cite web |url=http://www.rocemabra.com/~roger/tagg/generals/ |title=''The Generals of Gettysburg'' |author=Tagg, Larry |year=1998 |work= |publisher=Savas Publishing |accessdate=June 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022014655/http://www.rocemabra.com/~roger/tagg/generals/ |archivedate=October 22, 2014 |df= }} The situation continued to escalate. By August 10, 1859, 461 Americans with 14 cannon under [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] [[Silas Casey]] were opposed by five British warships mounting 70 guns and carrying 2,140 men. During this time, no shots were fired. The governor of the [[Colony of Vancouver Island]], [[James Douglas (Governor)|James Douglas]], ordered British [[Rear admiral (Royal Navy)|Rear Admiral]] [[Robert Lambert Baynes|Robert L. Baynes]] to land [[Royal Marines|marines]] on San Juan Island and engage the American soldiers under the command of Brigadier-General Harney. (Harney's forces had occupied the island since July 27, 1859.) Baynes refused, deciding that "two great nations in a war over a squabble about a pig" was foolish. Local commanding officers on both sides had been given essentially the same orders: defend yourselves, but absolutely do not fire the first shot. For several days, the British and U.S. soldiers exchanged insults, each side attempting to goad the other into firing the first shot, but discipline held on both sides, and thus no shots were fired. ==Resolution== When news about the crisis reached Washington and London, officials from both nations were shocked and took action to calm the potentially explosive international incident. In September, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[James Buchanan]] sent General [[Winfield Scott]] to negotiate with [[James Douglas (governor)|Governor Douglas]] and resolve the growing crisis. This was in the best interest of the United States, as sectional tensions within the country were increasing, soon to culminate in the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. Scott had calmed two other border crises between the two nations in the late 1830s. He arrived in the San Juans in October and began negotiations with Douglas. As a result of the negotiations, both sides agreed to retain joint military occupation of the island until a final settlement could be reached, reducing their presence to a token force of no more than 100 men. The "English Camp" was established on the north end of San Juan Island along the shoreline, for ease of supply and access; and the "American Camp" was created on the south end on a high, windswept meadow, suitable for artillery barrages against shipping. Today the [[Union Flag|Union Jack]] still flies above the "English Camp", being raised and lowered daily by park rangers, making it one of the few places without diplomatic status where U.S. government employees regularly hoist the flag of another country. [[File:San Juan Island NHP Eng Camp.JPG|thumb|right|File:San Juan Island NHP Eng Camp.JPG|Union Jack at the "English Camp" in San Juan Island National Historical Park]] During the years of joint [[military occupation]], the small British and American units on San Juan Island had an amicable mutual social life, visiting one another's camps to celebrate their respective national holidays and holding various athletic competitions. Park rangers tell visitors the biggest threat to peace on the island during these years was "the large amounts of alcohol available". This state of affairs continued for the next 12 years. The dispute was peacefully resolved after more than a decade of confrontation and military bluster, during which time the local British authorities consistently lobbied London to seize back the [[Puget Sound region]] entirely,{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} as the Americans were busy elsewhere with the Civil War. In 1866, the Colony of Vancouver Island was merged with the [[Colony of British Columbia (1858–66)|Colony of British Columbia]] to form an [[Colony of British Columbia (1866–71)|enlarged Colony of British Columbia]]. In 1871, the enlarged colony joined the newly formed [[Canadian Confederation|Dominion of Canada]]. That year, the United Kingdom and the United States signed the [[Treaty of Washington (1871)|Treaty of Washington]], which dealt with various differences between the two nations, including border issues involving the newly formed Dominion. Among the results of the treaty was the decision to resolve the San Juan dispute by [[international arbitration]], with German Emperor [[Wilhelm I of Germany|Wilhelm I]] chosen to act as arbitrator. Wilhelm referred the issue to a three-man arbitration commission which met in Geneva for nearly a year.{{cite web |title= The Pig War |work= San Juan Island National Historical Park |publisher= [[National Park Service]] |url= http://www.nps.gov/sajh/historyculture/the-pig-war.htm |accessdate= 2009-06-19}} On October 21, 1872, the commission decided in favor of the United States. The arbitrator chose the American-preferred marine boundary via [[Haro Strait]], to the west of the islands, over the British preference for [[Rosario Strait]] which lay to their east. [[File:British troops evacuate San Juan Island, Washington Terr, 1872 - Restored.jpg|thumb|British troops evacuate San Juan Island]] On November 25, 1872, the British withdrew their [[Royal Marines]] from the British Camp. The Americans followed by July 1874. Canadian politicians and public, already angry with the [[Oregon Treaty]], were once again upset that Britain had not looked after their interests, and Canada sought greater autonomy in international affairs. The Pig War is commemorated in [[San Juan Island National Historical Park]]. ==Key figures== * [[Henry Martyn Robert]] who later published ''[[Robert's Rules of Order]]'' was stationed on the island for much of the period.{{cite book |last= Vouri |first= Michael |title= The Pig War: Standoff at Griffin Bay |year= 1999 |publisher= Griffin Bay |isbn= 978-0-9634562-5-0 |pages= 273}} * Captain [[George Pickett]], later of [[Pickett's Charge]] fame, was in charge of the initial American landing force. * Captain [[Geoffrey Hornby]], commander of the initial British naval force deployed, would later be promoted to [[Admiral of the Fleet]], the highest rank in the Royal Navy, and earned a reputation as a pre-eminent tactician and fleet commander. ==See also== {{wiktionary|Pig War}} *[[Aroostook War]], the "Northeastern Boundary Dispute" *[[List of conflicts in the United States]] *[[List of conflicts in Canada]] *[[Military history of Canada]] *[[Military history of the United Kingdom]] *[[Military history of the United States]] *[[Point Roberts]] *[[War of the Stray Dog]], a brief war that began under similar circumstances. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |title=The Pig War |last=Baker |first=Betty |year=1969 |publisher=HarperCollins Canada |isbn=0060203331}} * {{cite book |title=The Pig War: The Most Perfect War in History |last=Coleman |first=E.C. |year=2009 |publisher=The History Press |isbn=978-0-7524-5227-2}} * {{cite book |title=The Pig War |last=Holtzen |first=Mark |year=2012 |publisher=CreateSpace |isbn=1475051360}} * {{cite book |title=The Pig War |last=Kaufman |first=Scott |year=2003 |publisher=Lexington Books |isbn=0739107291}} * {{cite book |title=The Pig War: The Last Canada–US Border Conflict |last=Neering |first=Rosemary |year=2011 |publisher=Heritage House Publishing Co. Ltd. |isbn=1926936019}} * {{cite book |title=The Pig War: Standoff at Griffin Bay |last=Vouri |first=Michael |year=1999 |publisher=Griffin Bay Book Store |isbn=0963456253}} ==External links== {{wiktionary|Pig War}} {{Commonscat|Pig War}} *[http://www.nps.gov/sajh/historyculture/the-pig-war.htm The Pig War], National Park Service *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080709060607/http://www.wahmee.com/pigwar.html The Pig War of San Juan Island] *[http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&file_id=5724 San Juan Island Pig War – Part 1], HistoryLink.org *[http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?displaypage=output.cfm&file_id=5037 Lyman Cutlar touches off Pig War between U.S. and Great Britain on June 15, 1859], HistoryLink.org {{American conflicts}} {{coord|48|27|41.91|N|123|00|23.81|W|region:US-WA_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=title}} [[Category:Pig War (1859)| ]] [[Category:Canada–United States border disputes]] [[Category:Battles and conflicts without fatalities]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1859]] [[Category:Pre-Confederation British Columbia]] [[Category:History of Washington (state)]] [[Category:Military history of Canada]] [[Category:History of the Pacific Northwest]] [[Category:Conflicts in Canada]] [[Category:Coast of British Columbia]] [[Category:Arbitration cases]]

[[File:Procesion del Silencio SLP175.JPG|thumb|Image of Our Lady of Solitude at the procession]] The '''Procession of Silence in San Luis Potosi''' is an annual event to mourn the [[Passion of Christ]] and honor [[Our Lady of Solitude]]. It occurs on the night of [[Good Friday]], beginning at the El Carmen Church, where it originated, and winds through the streets of the historic center of the [[San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí|city of San Luis Potosí]]. During the event there are the sounds of drums and bugles, but no participant or spectator speaks, giving the event its name. It is one of the most important [[Holy Week in Mexico|Holy Week observances in Mexico]] and was declared part of the cultural heritage of the state of [[San Luis Potosí]] in 2013.
==Significance== Organized by the Tradiciones Potosinas association,<ref name=50anos>{{cite news |author=Maria Esther Gonzalez |title= Celebra 50 años Procesion del Silencio |newspaper= Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=March 30, 2003 |page=13 }}</ref> the procession commemorates as an act of mourning the Passion of Christ.<ref name=mexdes>{{cite web |title=5 destinos para vivir la Semana Santa |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazine |location=Mexico City |url=http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/5-destinos-para-vivir-la-semana-santa-san-luis-potosi.html |accessdate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214024535/http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/5-destinos-para-vivir-la-semana-santa-san-luis-potosi.html |archivedate=December 14, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name=realizan>{{cite news |author=Manuel Vazquez |title= Realizan en SLP Procesión del Silencio |newspaper= El Norte |location=Monterrey |date=March 30, 2013 |page= 11 }}</ref> It is a reenactment of the [[Stations of the Cross]], with each station marked by a heavy platform with the relevant images.<ref name=buenviaje>{{cite web |title=La Procesión del Silencio: Tradición y fevor en San Luis Potosí |publisher=Buen Viaje Diario Turístico |location=Mexico City |url= http://www.revistabuenviaje.com/conocemexico/destinos/slp/procesion_silencio/procesion-del-silencio.php#.U6YCkZR5NAA |accessdate=June 22, 2014 }}</ref> This procession if one of the most important Holy Week observances in Mexico, one of the most important religious event for the state of San Luis Potosí and emblematic for the city.<ref name=50anos/><ref name=mexdes/><ref name=homenaje>{{cite press release |title= Ayuntamiento de la Capital realizará homenaje a los fundadores de la Procesión del Silencio |publisher= Government of San Luis Potosi |date= April 15, 2014 |url= http://sanluis.gob.mx/ayuntamiento-plaz-armas-ayuntamiento-de-la-capital-realizara-homenaje-los-fundadores-de-la-procesion-del-silencio/ |accessdate= June 22, 2014 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150402124125/http://sanluis.gob.mx/ayuntamiento-plaz-armas-ayuntamiento-de-la-capital-realizara-homenaje-los-fundadores-de-la-procesion-del-silencio/ |archivedate= April 2, 2015 |df= }}</ref> It is also a major tourist event, attractive over 160,000 visitors to the city, with about fifteen percent coming from outside of Mexico.<ref name=homenaje/><ref name=fervor>{{cite news |title= Siguen fieles con fervor Procesión del Silencio en SLP |newspaper= NOTIMEX |location=Mexico City |date=March 29, 2013 }}</ref><ref name=ofrecen>{{cite news |author=Ruth Berrones |title= Ofrecen potosinos singular procesion |newspaper= El Norte |location=Monterrey |date=April 20, 2000 |page=13 }}</ref>
==The main event== [[File:Procesion del Silencio SLP027.JPG|thumb|First brotherhood leaving the El Carmen church]] The procession takes place on Good Friday, in the historical center of the city of San Luis Potosi, which is filled with churches and colonial era buildings.<ref name=buenviaje/> Illuminated with candles, the area has a church-like atmosphere and even though thousands of spectators line the streets, no one will speak during the hours of the procession, which gives it the name.<ref name=mexdes/><ref name=realizan/><ref name=ofrecen/>
The main participants of the procession are the members of various religious brotherhoods, who carry and accompany large platforms with religious images through the streets.<ref name=buenviaje/> In 2013, there were thirty such brotherhoods<ref name=fervor/> which included the Cofradía del Virgen del Carmen, the Cofradía del Santo Entierro, Cofradía del Descendimiento, Cofradía del Ecce Homo and the Cofradía de la Soledad, which carries an image of Our Lady of Solitude.<ref name=realizan/><ref name=buenviaje/> The members of the various brotherhoods are identified by the colors of their garments, which identified their home parish and shows the influence of the processions of Seville. The most noticeable participants are the costaleros, which were a special tunic and pointed hoods with cloths covering the faces.<ref name=mexdes/><ref name=buenviaje/> The brotherhoods participate as a form of penance, with faces covered and some even walking with chains attached to their ankles.<ref name=mexdes/> Other participants include adults and children in various dress which include [[altar boy]]s, Nazarenes, Our Lady of [[Macarena, Seville|Macarena]], Roman soldiers, women wearing traditional Potosi [[rebozo]]s and carrying candles, bullfighters, politicians and artists.<ref name=mexdes/><ref name=buenviaje/><ref name=fervor/><ref name=mfago>{{cite web |author=Margaret Fago |title= Holy week procession grows into Mexico's largest such event |publisher= Catholic Voice |location=Oakland, CA |date=May 5, 2014 |url= http://www.catholicvoiceoakland.org/2014/05-05/inthisissue19.htm |accessdate=June 22, 2014 }}</ref> [[File:Procesion del Silencio SLP083.JPG|thumb|Women in rebozos in the procession]] The procession begins at the El Carmen Church at exactly 8pm.<ref name=mexdes/> The sound of a [[bugle]] summons the [[Praetorian Guard]] which marches from the Teatro de la Paz to the El Carmen Church. The centurian knocks three times at the main door and the bugler on horseback clears the way and silences the crowd for the procession.<ref name=buenviaje/> The procession contains hundreds of people and begins by crossing the Plaza del Carmen in front of the church. Just this portion of the procession takes two hours.<ref name=mfago/> The entire event lasts over four hours and winds its way along the main streets of the historic center, passing landmarks such as the Mask Museum, the Government Palace the main city plaza and the cathedral over 3.5 km.<ref name=50anos/><ref name=fervor/><ref name=mfago/> The main focal points are the platforms carried by members of the brotherhoods, which can weigh up to 500 kilograms, which bear religious images adorned with fresh flowers. Some of the platforms have been made by local artisans and others imported from [[Seville, Spain]].<ref name=mfago/> The participants walk slowly and solemnly, with the pace measured by drumbeats.<ref name=mfago/> At certain points in the procession, trumpets are sounded.<ref name=buenviaje/> There are twenty three main platform, with the end of the procession marked by that dedicated to Our Lady of Solitude. This image is ornate Baroque and created by [[Manuel Tolsá]].<ref name=buenviaje/><ref name=fervor/> and wears a Seville style cloak.<ref name=50anos/> {{clear}}
==The procession as part of Holy Week in San Luis Potosi== The procession is the highlight of two weeks of activities related to Holy Week, which include those of religious, cultural and sporting nature, beginning on the Viernes de Dolores, the Friday before [[Palm Sunday]]. On this day, crowds gather on a small alley called Callejón del Buche to create altars dedicated to the Virgin Mary as [[Our Lady of Sorrows]].<ref name=50anos/><ref name=buenviaje/> During the rest of the week more altars are assembled depicting the various Stations of the Cross, with some of these destined to be carried during the Good Friday procession.<ref name=mfago/>
[[Palm Sunday]] is marked with a simple procession to the city cathedral for the blessing of palms. On [[Maundy Thursday]], there is another procession with seven platforms that visit the various main neighborhoods of the city and their main churches.<ref name=buenviaje/> In the churches, the images of saints are covered on purple cloths as a sign of mourning, bread is distributed to remember the [[Last Supper]] and sprigs of [[chamomile]] are blessed.<ref name=mexdes/> During the day on Good Friday, the main event is a reenactment of the crucifixion in the San Juan de Guadalupe neighborhood,<ref name=ofrecen/> and on [[Holy Saturday]], the [[Burning of Judas]] occurs on the Plaza de los Fundadores.<ref name=buenviaje/>
The Holy Week season stretches for two weeks and various secular events are sponsored by government and private entities during this time. These include art exhibitions, concerts, conferences, guided tours and volleyball and basketball tournaments. They also include a half marathon between [[Venado]] and [[Charcas, San Luis Potosi|Charcas]] and a national youth tennis tournament.<ref name=50anos/><ref name=buenviaje/><ref name=culturales>{{cite news |title= Presentan actividades culturales de Semana Santa en San Luis Potosí. Destacan la Procesión del Silencio y la Fiesta de la Luz. |newspaper= NOTIMEX |location=Mexico City |date=February 28, 2008 }}</ref>
==History== The modern event has its origins in the traditions of processions during Holy Week established in [[New Spain]] early in the colonial period, which included the hiding of the faces of participants.<ref name=buenviaje/> The first procession of silence was instituted by the [[Carmelites]] in [[Mexico City]].<ref name=culturales/>
However, this particular procession was officially established in 1954.<ref name=realizan/><ref name=ilam>{{cite web |title=From the blog |publisher= ILAM Foundation |url= http://www.ilam.org/index.php/es/s-o-s-patrimonio/noticias/390-procesion-del-silencio |accessdate=June 22, 2014 }}</ref> At this time, bullfighters Fermín Rivera, Carmelite priest Nicolás de San José and others began a small event to enact the Stations of the Cross and pay homage to Our Lady of Solitude by the guild of bullfighters at the El Carmen church.<ref name=fervor/><ref name=mfago/><ref name=culturales/> It is based on the annual procession in Seville, Spain in honor of Our Lady of Macarena, although this version is dedicated to Our Lady of Solitude, because of the devotion of the bullfighters to this image of the Virgin Mary.<ref name=fervor/>
Today, it is the only procession in Mexico to include altars depicting all stations of the cross.<ref name=mfago/> It was declared part of the cultural heritage of the state of San Luis Potosí in 2013 as well as the most important civic and religious event of the state.<ref name=ilam/> In 2014, the city paid homage to the founders of the modern event, including Fermín Rivera, María de los Ángeles Agüero Ereño, Marco Tulio Jiménez, Carlos Artolózaga Noriega and Juan Hernández Auces.<ref name=homenaje/> {{commons category|Procesión del Silencio, San Luis de Pötosí}}
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Holy Week processions|Mexico]] [[Category:Religion in Mexico]]

{{Distinguish|Rape of Belgium}} {{Rape}} In 2004, the incidence of rapes recorded by the police in [[Belgium]] was 28.4 per 100,000 people, according to data by [[UNODC]]; in 2008 it was 29.5 per 100,000 people.http://www.unodc.org/documents/data-and-analysis/Crime-statistics/Sexual_violence_sv_against_children_and_rape.xls Belgium has been reported as being one of the countries with the highest rate of [[rape]].{{cite web|author=March 17, 2014 10:35 GMT |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/belgium-sexual-harassment-punished-imprisonment-under-new-law-1440582 |title=Belgium: Sexual Harassment Punished With Imprisonment Under New Law |publisher=Ibtimes.co.uk |date=2012-02-16 |accessdate=2014-03-18}} ==Law== Rape in Belgium is defined by Article 375 of the Penal Code as "any act of sexual penetration, of whatever sort and by whatever means, committed on a non-consenting person".{{cite web|url=http://sgdatabase.unwomen.org/searchDetail.action?measureId=10080&baseHREF=country&baseHREFId=213 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318212005/http://sgdatabase.unwomen.org/searchDetail.action?measureId=10080&baseHREF=country&baseHREFId=213 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-03-18 |title=The Secretary Generals database on violence against women |publisher=Sgdatabase.unwomen.org |date= |accessdate=2014-03-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/cgi_loi/loi_a1.pl?DETAIL=1867060801%2FF&caller=list&row_id=1&numero=2&rech=4&cn=1867060801&table_name=LOI&nm=1867060850&la=F&dt=CODE+PENAL&language=fr&fr=f&choix1=ET&choix2=ET&fromtab=loi_all&trier=promulgation&chercher=t&sql=dt+contains++%27CODE%27%26+%27PENAL%27and+actif+%3D+%27Y%27&tri=dd+AS+RANK+&imgcn.x=41&imgcn.y=12 |title=Loi - Wet |publisher=Ejustice.just.fgov.be |date= |accessdate=2014-03-18}} Marital rape is also illegal under this law. Apart from criminal proceedings, committing marital rape has also consequences in a [[divorce]] case. The new amendments to the Civil Code regulating marriage and divorce, that came into effect in September 2007, state that any of the spouses, following a divorce, may receive [[alimony]] if they need the money, but a spouse who has committed rape or other violent crimes against the other spouse cannot receive alimony. Article 301 reads:
The court may refuse to grant the application for a alimony if the defendant proves that the applicant has committed a serious offense that rendered it impossible to continue living together. Under no circumstances will alimony be given to a spouse who was found guilty of an act referred to in '''Articles 375''', 398-400, 402, 403 or 405 of the Penal Code, committed against the person of the defendant, or an attempt to commit an act referred to in '''Articles 375''', 393, 394 or 397 of the Code against the same person.Text in French: "Le tribunal peut refuser de faire droit à la demande de pension si le défendeur prouve que le demandeur a commis une faute grave ayant rendu impossible la poursuite de la vie commune. En aucun cas, la pension alimentaire n'est accordée au conjoint reconnu coupable d'un fait visé aux articles 375, 398 à 400, 402, 403 ou 405 du Code pénal, commis contre la personne du défendeur, ou d'une tentative de commettre un fait visé aux articles 375, 393, 394 ou 397 du même Code contre cette même personne."[http://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/cgi_loi/loi_a1.pl?DETAIL=1804032130%2FF&caller=list&row_id=1&numero=11&rech=14&cn=1804032130&table_name=LOI&nm=1804032150&la=F&dt=CODE+CIVIL&language=fr&fr=f&choix1=ET&choix2=ET&fromtab=loi_all&trier=promulgation&chercher=t&sql=dt+contains++%27CODE%27%26+%27CIVIL%27and+actif+%3D+%27Y%27&tri=dd+AS+RANK+&imgcn.x=34&imgcn.y=10]
==Prevalence== In 2011, Belgian Institute for the Equality of Women and Men published a report on "Women and men in Belgium", which noted that in 2008, according to police report, 87% of victims of rape (89% for collective rape) were female.{{cite web |url=http://www.womenlobby.org/spip.php?action=acceder_document&arg=3144&cle=008f9546f38740223b896ddf3b19887af14efb64&file=pdf%2F2714_belgium_lr.pdf |format=PDF |title=NATIONAL ANALYSIS Belgium |publisher=womenlobby.org}} The survey, carried out by Belgian Institute and titled ''Experience of men and women in gender based violence'', included the following figures; {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Relation || Women || Men || Total |- |Partner||30.8%||5.7%||17.5% |- |Family||27.4%||16.2%||21.5% |- |Acquaintance||11.3%||15.8%||13.6% |- |Work||17.2%||21.9%||19.7% |- |Unknown||13.3%||40.4%||27.7% |} According to ''[[De Morgen]]'', from 2009 and 2011 the number of reported rape cases increased from 3,360 to 4,038, an increase of more than 20 percent. According to a report by ''[[De Standaard]]'', the sentences for rape is considerably lower than it is usually expected. For example, a person who had raped his 13-year-old stepdaughter was sentenced to 2.5 years. In another case, the criminal was sentenced to two years for repeated rape of two girls younger than 15; one of the victims was pregnant.{{cite web|author=Practical Ethics |url=http://blog.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk/2011/05/belgium-where-rapists-and-muffin-thieves-are-treated-alike/ |title=Belgium: where rapists and muffin thieves are treated alike | Practical Ethics |publisher=Blog.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk |date=2011-05-13 |accessdate=2014-03-18}} ==See also== * [[Rape statistics]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Rape by country]] [[Category:Crime in Belgium]] [[Category:Crimes against women]] [[Category:Sexual violence]]

[[Image:ReadingAmReg01.JPG|right|thumb|Crews at the finish at Reading Amateur Regatta]] '''Reading Amateur Regatta''' is a [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]] [[regatta]], on the [[River Thames]] in [[England]] which takes place at [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], [[Berkshire]] on the reach above [[Caversham Lock]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/berkshire/content/articles/2008/06/11/reading_amateur_regatta_feature.shtml Reading Amateur Regatta], [[BBC Radio Berkshire]], 2008.</ref>
The regatta takes place in June and attracts top crews from around the UK.<ref>British Rowing Almanac - All years</ref> Racing takes place on the 1500-metres downstream course that stretches from [[St Mary's Island, River Thames|St Mary's Island]] until just short of [[Reading Rowing Club]] clubhouse. The regatta takes place on Saturday and Sunday in June and its importance stems from its date, being immediately before entries close for [[Henley Royal Regatta]].
Reading Amateur Regatta was established in 1842 although it had a chequered history until the 1870s, when [[Reading Rowing Club]] was founded and revived interest in it.<ref name=History>[http://www.reading-amateur-regatta.org Reading Amateur Regatta - History Section]</ref> Its re-establishment was also encouraged by the founding of the [[Reading Town Regatta|Reading Working Men's Regatta]] on the lower lock reach above [[Sonning Lock]] in 1877.
Another hiatus occurred after [[World War I]], but thenceforth the regatta grew from strength to strength requiring various adaptations to accommodate the entry level.<ref name=History/> This resulted in a review in 1999 which saw two-lane racing reintroduced on a 1500 metres course by changing from launch to bank umpiring. An ironical conclusion perhaps as in 1844 a ferryman had spent four months in [[Reading Gaol]] for attacking an umpire and tipping him into the river with a punt pole in retaliation for disqualification in the previous year's regatta.

{{Infobox motorsport championship | name = SCCA Spec Racer Ford Pro Series | logo = SpecRacerFordField2010SCCANationalRunoffs.jpg | image-size = | caption = Field for the 2010 SCCA National Runoffs | category = [[Spec racing|Spec formula]] [[sports car racing]] | country/region = {{flagicon|USA}} [[United States]] | inaugural = 1994 | inaugural2 = | folded = 2011 | classes = | drivers = | riders = | teams = | constructors = [[SCCA Enterprises]] | engines = [[Ford]] | tyres = [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]] Eagle | champion driver = [[Scott Rettich]] (2011) | champion rider = | champion team = [[Alliance Autosport]] (2011) | manufacturer = | constructor = | website = | current_season = | race_director = }}
The '''SCCA Spec Racer Ford Pro Series''' was a [[sports car racing]] series in the [[United States]]. The series existed between 1994 and 2002 the series was revived for 2010 and 2011.
==History==
===Early years=== The [[Spec Racer Ford]] was introduced in 1994 after [[Renault]] pulled out of the Spec Racer project. [[SCCA Pro Racing]] introduced the pro series soon after [[Ford]] wanted to support the Spec Racer. The first season saw fields of around 25 cars. [[David Tenney]] won the first ever Spec Racer Ford Pro Series race on July 2, 1994 at the [[Des Moines Street Circuit]]. Tenney won the race after a lengthy battle for the lead with [[Keith Scharf]].<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing News|year=1994|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|page=1|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1994-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104102949/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1994-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref> The second race at [[Watkins Glen International]] marked the first win of many for [[Warren Stillwell]], who would win numerous races in Spec Racer Ford classes. Stillwell took the inaugural championship with one race left in the championship. Keith Scharf finished second in the championship followed by [[Bob Boudinot]].<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing News|year=1994|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|page=14|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1994-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104102949/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1994-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref>
Warrenn Stillwell repeated his championship in 1995 again taking the championship one race early.<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing Results|year=1995|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|page=10|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1995-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104101117/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1995-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref>
===Golden Era=== For the 1996 season the fields exploded, 55 cars were entered in the first race, only 45 could start.<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing Results|year=1996|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|page=1|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1996-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104102557/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1996-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref> The 1994 and 1995 seasons saw only 5 races on the calendar, two races were added for 1996. Many drivers were in fact amateur racers making their pro racing debut. The sheer number of cars in combination with a street circuit resulted in 18 cars crashing at the [[Grand Prix of Minnesota]].<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing Results|year=1996|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|page=7|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1996-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104102557/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1996-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref> [[James Goughary Jr.]] won the race and went on to win the championship with [[Keith Scharf]] finishing second and Warren Stillwell finishing third in the championship.
The following season, 1997, saw nine races on the calendar including 2 double-headers. Stillwell retook the crown, winning four races. He was closely followed by [[Robert Mumm]], only 2 points made the difference in the end. The races were not very tense, only 11 lead changes throughout the season with 6 races seeing no lead changes. The sixth round of the championship at [[Heartland Park]] was an exception with 7 lead changes. There were only 0.210 seconds between the winning driver ([[Robbert Mumm]]) and the number two ([[Leo Capaldi]]), with Stillwell finishing third.<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing Results|year=1997|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|pages=10, 20|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1997-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104101903/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1997-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref>
For 1998 the SCCA Pro Racing shortened the calendar to 7 races. The championship was decided in the final round. At the final round the Spec Racer Ford Pro Series supported the [[FIA GT]] World Schampionships at [[Homestead-Miami Speedway]]. Going in the final round John Strickler had scored 96 points and Stillwell 93. Qualifying was close with Strickler on [[pole position]] and Stillwell starting fourth. During the race Stillwell crashed in the 11th round and Strickler went on to win the race and the championship.<ref>{{cite book|title=SCCA Pro Racing Results|year=1998|publisher=SCCA Pro Racing Media Relations|page=13|url=http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1998-SRF.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104101340/http://scca.com/documents/Pro%20Racing/Archives/Spec%20Racer%20Ford/1998-SRF.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-04}}</ref>
1999 saw again large fields with an average of 36 cars per race. [[Jack Willes]] decided the championship in the prefinal round at [[Watkins Glen International]]. The battle for the second place in the championship was tight. This was decided during the final round at [[Sebring International Raceway]]. With Goughary, Jr. and Tilbor competing for second place. Goughary finished third, in front of Tilbor who was fourth, thus winning the second place in the championship.
With fields still as large as before and relative rookies competing for top honors the series was still going strong into the new millennium. Stillwell decided the championship, in his signature style, one race early.<ref>{{cite web|title=SCCA Spec Racer Ford Pro Series 2000|url=http://www.driverdb.com/standings/3442-2000/|work=DriverDB.com|accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref> New in the top three were second placed [[Bobby Sak]] and third placed [[John Black (racing driver)|John Black]].
In its eighth season, in 2001, the series supported the [[Trans-Am Series]], [[SCCA World Challenge]] and the [[NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|NASCAR Winston Cup Series]] at [[Sears Point Raceway]]. [[Keith Scharf]] took the title after nine rounds of racing. Stillwell was on course to win his fifth title, but he lost valuable points when he had to sit out round five. Round five was the only [[oval racing]] event on the calendar. At [[Chicago Motor Speedway]], supporting the [[ASA National Tour]], only 17 cars started the race. Scharf started from pole and won the 50 lap race, thus gaining points on championship fore runners Stillwell and Goughary Jr. who did not start the race. Scharf did not finish outside the top six and took his first title.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scharf reigns supreme in 2001 Pro Spec Racer|url=http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/01review.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030710031135/http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/01review.html|archivedate=2003-07-10|work=SCCA PRO SPEC RACER 2001 REVIEW|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>
Stillwell retook the title in 2002, winning three races and capturing seven podium finishes out of ten races.<ref>{{cite web|title=2002 Point Standings|url=http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/02/day/points.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031230174913/http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/02/day/points.html|archivedate=2003-12-30|work=SCCA Pro Racing|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>
===Cancellation=== For the 2003 season the series was split up in an Atlantic Tour and a Pacific Tour.<ref>{{cite web|title=SCCA Pro Racing Announces 2003 Pro Spec Racer Schedule|url=http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/news/02news25.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030708040532/http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/news/02news25.html|archivedate=2003-07-08|work=SCCA Pro Spec Racer News|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref> But instead of creating a series where drivers from the whole country could compete for the title, fields were split in half. May 20, 2003 SCCA Pro Racing canceled the remainder of the Atlantic and Pacific Tours.<ref>{{cite web|title=CHECKERED FLAG FALLS ON PRO SPEC RACER SERIES|url=http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/news/03news06.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031013035920/http://www.sccapro.com/srfps/news/03news06.html|archivedate=2003-10-13|work=SCCA PRO SPEC RACER NEWS|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref> [[Shawn Morrison (racing driver)|Shawn Morrison]] was the last driver to win a Pro Spec Racer event.
===Revival=== The Spec Racer Ford Pro Series was revived by the [[Sports Car Club of America|SCCA]] in 2010. The series was launched together with the [[SCCA Pro Formula Enterprises]]. In the new racing format every race-weekend features two races. 57 drivers entered the first race at [[Road Atlanta]]. Of the 52 drivers who started the race, [[Brian Schofield (racing driver)|Brian Schofield]] finished first with a margin of 0.145 seconds over [[Tray Ayres]].<ref>{{cite web|title=SCCA Pro Spec Racer Ford Round 1|url=http://www.sccaproracing.com/files/results/10-srf-atl-race1-.PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621115723/http://www.sccaproracing.com/files/results/10-srf-atl-race1-.PDF|archivedate=2013-06-21|work=SCCA Pro Racing|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref> For the second raceweekend, at [[New Jersey Motorsports Park|Thunderbolt Raceway]], fields were drastically smaller with 18 cars on the grid. [[Scott Rettich]] took his first Pro Spec Racer win. A record low competitor count was achieved at [[Brainerd International Raceway]], only 12 drivers joined the grid.<ref>{{cite web|title=SCCA Pro Spec Racer Ford Round 8|url=http://www.sccaproracing.com/files/results/FIN-Race-Results-1-_116.PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621115749/http://www.sccaproracing.com/files/results/FIN-Race-Results-1-_116.PDF|archivedate=2013-06-21|work=SCCA Pro Racing|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref> After ten races Rettich took the title with five point separating him from the number two Ayres.<ref>{{cite web|title=SCCA Spec Racer Ford Pro Series 2010|url=http://www.driverdb.com/standings/3442-2010/|work=DriverDB.com|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref>
The series was renewed for a second season in 2011. The season would be a disappointing one from an organizer point of view. The largest field was at the [[Grand Prix de Trois-Rivières]] with 21 cars, the smallest however was just five cars at the season finale at Road Atlanta. Tray Ayres would win, what would be the last, Pro SRF race. Rettich won three races and won the championship. SRF veteran Richard Spicer won four races, but had less podium finishes, thus he finished second in the standings.
Five days after the last race of the season, SCCA Pro Racing announced that the Pro Spec Ford and the Pro Formula Enterprises would not return in 2012. The organisation stated that the series was not viable in the current economic environment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pro SRF and Pro Formula Enterprises Will Not Return in 2012|url=http://sccaproracing.com/story.php?ID=2328|work=SCCA Pro Racing|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref>
==The car== {{see also|Spec Racer Ford}}
The Spec Racer Ford is an open cockpit sportsracer produced by [[SCCA Enterprises]]. The car features a 1.9L [[Ford Escort (North America)|Ford Escort]] engine in the [[Rear-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|rear]]. The engine is an [[inline-4]] [[SOHC]] with 8 valves with a [[Hemi]] head. The engine produces 105 [[horsepower]].
The car has a tube frame [[chassis]]. The bodywork is made out of [[fiberglass]]. The [[gearbox]] is a [[transaxle]] type and features five forward speeds and one reverse.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spec Racer Ford|url=http://www.scca-enterprises.com/specracer.html|work=SCCA Enterprises|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref>

'''Senninha''' is a [[Brazil]]ian comic book series created by Rogério Martins and Ridaut Dias Jr., whose main character is based upon [[Formula One]] world champion [[Ayrton Senna]].
Senninha was launched in 1994 by the publisher [[Editora Abril|Abril]], some months before [[Death of Ayrton Senna|Senna's death]]. After Senna's death, the comics have become very popular and remain the leading the sales until 1999, when in the same year the comics began to be published by [[:pt:Brainstore|Brainstore]] however the series was canceled in 2000 after few issues. In 2008 the comic returned by the publisher HQM, but due to poor sales and promotion was canceled again.
All profits from licensing of the character go to the [[Instituto Ayrton Senna]].
==Characters== [[File:Senninha 2.jpg|thumb|Senninha]] * '''Senninha''', "little Senna," is the main character of the series, with characteristics very similar to Ayrton Senna, including unruly hair, a bulbous nose and red overalls (like the [[McLaren]] team for which Senna was best known), as well as being friendly, determined and sometimes rushed. He is eight years old. During the initial run, he wore a blue jumpsuit (like the [[Williams Grand Prix Engineering|Williams]] team that Senna was driving for at the time of the character's creation) and a simple helmet. In issue #10 his helmet became a magical character called Meu Herói. * '''Meu Herói''', "my hero," is the magical helmet of Senninha, colored green, yellow and blue like Senna's helmet (which was predominantly yellow, with one green and one blue horizontal stripe.) To most other people it is a normal helmet and only magical entities and persons as special as Senninha (such as [[Juan Manuel Fangio]], who made a posthumous appearance in the comics in 1995) can see and hear it. * '''Neco''' is the mechanical inventor of the group. He is of Japanese descent and the twin brother of Coni. He is eight years old. Until issue #9 he was called Nico. * '''Gabi''' is an artist and the sensitive member of the group. She is eight years old. * '''Becão and Bicão''' are Senninha's twin helmet-wearing sheepdogs. Becão's helmet is blue with a white band and he thinks and acts like a human. Bicão's helmet is white with a blue stripe and he acts like any other ordinary dog, making a mess wherever he goes. * '''Johnny''' is the heartthrob of the group and good at designing racing cars. He is ten years old. * '''Tala Larga''' is the reporter in the group, who always records the racers with his camera, and often tries to interview Senninha, of whom he is a big fan. He is eight years old. The character was inspired by [[Galvão Bueno]]. * '''Déia''' is the detective in the group. She is eight years old. * '''Coni''' Neco's twin sister and the "economist" of the group. She is eight years old. * '''Marcha Lenta,''' whose name means "idle", is often shown sleeping. When awake, he normally interacts with Tala, as his cameraman. He is eight years old. * '''JJ''' is crazy about basketball and computer science, as well as a top student in his class. He is the only black character in the group. He is ten years old. * '''Téo''' is the younger brother of Senninha and can be a brat. He often annoys Johnny, who does not like him very much. He is six years old. The character was Inspired by Ayrton Senna's younger brother Leonardo. * '''Gigi''' is the older sister of Senninha. She loves to talk on the phone. She is thirteen years old. The character was inspired by Viviane, Ayrton Senna's older sister. * '''Braço Duro''' is the leader of a rival gang to Senninha's group. He is always trying to win races and usually cheats. He hates losing to Senninha. He is nine years old. The character was inspired by Senna's rival Formula One drivers [[Alain Prost]] and [[Michael Schumacher]]. His name (literally "hard arm") comes from a Brazilian slang for bad drivers. * '''Rebimboca''' is the mechanic of Braço's gang. He always copies Johnny's original ideas of cars design. He is nine years old. * '''Bate-Pino''' has a stutter and always takes a long time to complete a sentence. He is ten years old. * '''Pé-de-Breque''' is a big, fat member of Braço's gang and the typical dim-witted comic relief character. He is eleven years old. * '''Tamborim''' is a purple mongrel cat and the mascot of Braço's gang.
==History== Senninha was designed by Rogerio Martins Jr and Ridaut Days in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|last=Billaud|first=Norbert|title=A small pilot with a big heart|url=http://www.fanaticf1.com/formule1/7328-Television-A-Senna-Video.html|publisher=Fanatic F1|date=4 October 2008|accessdate=21 August 2012|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419205723/http://www.fanaticf1.com/formule1/7328-Television-A-Senna-Video.html|archivedate=19 April 2014|df=}}</ref> The pair was looking to publish the character but were low on money. They met with Ayrton Senna who suggested the design be based on himself.
The first publication was on February 27, 1994. It was published by Editora Abril and made available free to every school in Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senna's World: SENNINHA|url=http://www.sennaworld.com/senninha.html|publisher=Senna World|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Senninha and His Crew # 4 on newsstands|url= http://hqmaniacs.uol.com.br/principal.asp?acao=noticias&cod_noticia=16610|publisher=UOL|date=23 July 2008|accessdate=21 August 2012|language=Portuguese}}</ref> The publications of the character transferred to Brainstore before being cancelled later that year. The comics were also sold in various bookstores in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|title=' UN FIGLIO E LA FERRARI'|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1995/05/01/un-figlio-la-ferrari.html|publisher=La Repubblica|date=1 May 1995|accessdate=28 September 2012|language=Italian}}</ref> Senninha returned in 2008 with new publishers HQM Publisher.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ramone|first=Marcus|title=CHILDREN'S SERIES HQM # 1 - Senninha|url=http://www.universohq.com/quadrinhos/2010/review_SeninhaTurma1.cfm|publisher=Universe HQ|date=October 2010|accessdate=21 August 2012|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120627141141/http://www.universohq.com/quadrinhos/2010/review_SeninhaTurma1.cfm|archivedate=27 June 2012|df=}}</ref> All of the sales of Senninha contribute to the [[Instituto Ayrton Senna]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Knoploch|first=Carlos|title=Viviane Senna não gosta de automobilismo, mas acompanha carreira do filho Bruno|url=http://extra.globo.com/esporte/viviane-senna-nao-gosta-de-automobilismo-mas-acompanha-carreira-do-filho-bruno-30358.html|publisher=Globo|date=7 November 2010|accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref>
===Merchandising=== Senninha's name has been used on more than 370 products ranging from shirts to helicopters.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fundación Senna: el mejor homenaje|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/spanish/misc/newsid_3670000/3670163.stm|publisher=[[BBC Mundo]] ([[BBC]])|date=29 April 2004|accessdate=28 September 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref> A brand of eyewear created by the House of Watchmakers under Senninha's name is aimed at children under the age of twelve.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diário Do Nordeste Negocios|url=http://diariodonordeste.globo.com/1999/11/11/020007.htm|publisher=Globo|date=11 November 1999|accessdate=28 September 2012|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131223093902/http://diariodonordeste.globo.com/1999/11/11/020007.htm|archivedate=23 December 2013|df=}}</ref>
===Video game adaption=== DiverBras Entertainment developed a Senninha licensed racing arcade game entitled ''Senninha GP'' in 2008. The game was developed in Brazil by a team of 25 developers. It was first released in São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro.<ref>{{cite web|title="Senninha GP" pode ganhar versão para consoles|url=http://tecnologia.uol.com.br/ultnot/2008/08/13/ult530u6281.jhtm|publisher=UOL|date=13 August 2008|accessdate=28 September 2012|language=Portuguese}}</ref>
===Cartoon=== Between the 1990s and 2000s several commercial animations and some short films were developed.
In 2015 a cartoon series of short episodes, "Zupt com o Senninha", was aired on educational channels such as [[Discovery Kids]] and [[TV Cultura]].<ref>{{citar web|url=http://anmtv.xpg.uol.com.br/ayrton-senna-ganha-animacao-no-discovery-kids/|título=Ayrton Senna ganha animação no Discovery Kids |autor=|data=05/12/2014|publicado=ANMTV|acessodata=}}</ref> In 2018 a cartoon series called "Senninha na Pista Maluca" debuted on the children's channel [[Gloobinho]].<ref>{{citar web|url=http://www.meioemensagem.com.br/home/midia/2018/07/16/gloobinho-estreia-serie-animada-do-senninha.html|titulo=Gloobinho estreia série animada do Senninha|data=16/07/2018|obra=Meio & Mensagem|publicado=meioemensagem.com.br|acessodata=03/10/2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

Ireland | language = English }} '''''The Last Confession of Alexander Pearce''''' is a 2008 Australian film directed by [[Michael James Rowland]] starring Irish actors [[Adrian Dunbar]] as Philip Conolly and [[Ciarán McMenamin]] as [[bushranger]] [[Alexander Pearce]] and an ensemble Australian cast, including [[Dan Wyllie]], [[Don Hany]] and [[Chris Haywood]]. The film was shot on location in [[Tasmania]] and [[Sydney]] between April and May 2008. The film was nominated for the 2010 [[Rose d'Or]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rosedor.ch/en/history/2010/nominees/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707002245/http://www.rosedor.ch/en/history/2010/nominees/ |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }}{{cite news| url=http://www.rte.ie/about/awards/sdfasdf.html | work=RTÉ News | title=Rose D'Or Nomination for "The Last Confession Of Alexander Pearce" | date=24 June 2010}} Best Drama at the 6th Annual [[Irish Film and Television Awards]],http://www.ifta.ie/ Best Drama at the 2009 [[Australian Film Institute]] Awards,{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/afi-awards-nominees/story-e6frg8mf-1225792081869 | title=2009 AFI awards nominees | date=28 October 2009 | work=The Australian}} won Best Documentary at the 2009 [[Inside Film Awards]]{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/entertainment/film/2009-inside-film-award-winners/2009/11/19/1258219913042.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=2009 Inside Film award winners | date=19 November 2009}} and the director Michael James Rowland was nominated in the Best Director (Telemovie) category in the 2009 Australian Directors Guild Awards.http://www.adg.org.au// ==Premise and title== The film follows the final days of Irish convict and [[bushranger]] [[Alexander Pearce]]'s life as he awaits execution. In 1824 the British [[penal colony]] of [[Van Diemen's Land]] is little more than a living hell. Chained to a wall in the darkness of a cell under [[Hobart Gaol]], Pearce is visited by Father Philip Conolly, the parish priest of the fledgling colony and a fellow Irishman. Pearce wishes to tell the priest his recollection of the horrors he endured in the three months spent traversing the brutal wilderness of [[Van Diemen's Land]]. Conolly struggles to reconcile his desire to grant absolution to the convict with the story Pearce tells him. The title of the film comes from the remarkable interaction between Philip Conolly and Alexander Pearce days before Pearce is executed. ''The Last Confession of Alexander Pearce'' is presented as a psychoanalytical [[historical epic]]. The relatively underscored aspect of Pearce's crime and confessions is the murder of fellow escapees and the alleged [[human cannibalism|cannibalism]].see [[Alexander_Pearce#Escape and cannibalism]] for interpretations of the multiple confessions The film details the convict's relinquishing psyche as he finds himself succumbing to the inevitability of his imminent execution. For much of the film, the complex relationship between Pearce and Conolly is examined. The circumstances and motives of Pearce's execution are, too, put into question by Rowland. ==Production== Producer and co-writer [[Nial Fulton]] began developing ''The Last Confession of Alexander Pearce'' in [[Ireland]] in 1998 and [[Filmmaking|production]] began on the project in Australia in the summer of 2006. The film was commissioned and financed by the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], [[RTÉ]], [[BBC Northern Ireland]], [[Screen Australia]] and Screen Tasmania. ''The Last Confession of Alexander Pearce'' was inspired by the true story of an escape from the infamous [[Sarah Island (Tasmania)|Sarah Island]] penal settlement in [[Macquarie Harbour]], Van Diemen's Land in 1822 by Irish convict and bushranger [[Alexander Pearce]] and the subsequent confession he made to the Hobart priest Phillip Conolly days before he was executed for the murder of fellow convict Thomas Cox. ===Script=== Written by Michael James Rowland and [[Nial Fulton]], the script draws on all four confessions made by [[Alexander Pearce]], but principally on the confessions he made to Commandant John Cuthbertson and the final confession made to the [[priest]] Phillip Conolly. In many places the script uses the exact words written down in these confessions. ===Principal cast=== *[[Adrian Dunbar]] as Philip Connolly *[[Ciarán McMenamin]] as [[Alexander Pearce]] *[[Dan Wyllie]] as Robert Greenhill *[[Don Hany]] as John Mather *[[Bob Franklin (comedian)|Bob Franklin]] as Matthew Travers *[[Chris Haywood]] as Reverend [[Robert Knopwood]] ==Van Diemen's Land / Tasmania== Shot over five weeks on location in Tasmania and Sydney in 2008, the film used locations around [[Derwent Bridge, Tasmania|Derwent Bridge]], [[Lake St Clair (Tasmania)|Lake St Clair]], [[Nelson Falls]], [[Huon Valley|the Huon Valley]], [[Mount Wellington (Tasmania)|Mount Wellington]] and [[Callan Park Hospital for the Insane|Callan Park]], a former asylum in [[Rozelle]]. Many of the filming locations were selected as they were places Alexander Pearce may have passed through on his escape from Sarah Island. ==Critical response and reviews== ''The Last Confession of Alexander Pearce'' received positive reviews internationally from film critics. *''[[The Age]]''{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/film/dvd-reviews/the-last-confession-of-alexander-pearce/2009/02/12/1234028188252.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | first=Sacha | last=Molitorisz | title=The Last Confession of Alexander Pearce | date=12 February 2009}} *''[[The Australian]]''{{cite news| {{Infobox song | name = The Love of Richard Nixon | cover = TheLoveOfRichardNixon.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Manic Street Preachers]] | album = [[Lifeblood (album)|Lifeblood]] | released = 18 October 2004 | format = CD, DVD | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop rock]], [[alternative rock]], [[synthpop]] | length = | label = [[Epic Records|Epic]] | writer = [[James Dean Bradfield]], [[Nicky Wire]], [[Sean Moore (musician)|Sean Moore]] | producer = Greg Haver, [[Tom Elmhirst]] | prev_title = [[There by the Grace of God]] | prev_year = 2002 | next_title = [[Empty Souls]] | next_year = 2005 }} "'''The Love of Richard Nixon'''" ({{Audio|Manic Street Preachers The Love Of Richard Nixon.ogg|sample}}) is a song by [[Wales|Welsh]] [[alternative rock]] band [[Manic Street Preachers]]. It was released in 2004 by record label [[Epic Records|Epic]] as the first single from their seventh studio album, ''[[Lifeblood (album)|Lifeblood]]''. == Content == The song is, according to the band, "a soundtrack to disillusion, hatred, love and never giving up".Martin Clarke, ''Manic Street Preachers: Sweet Venom'' (Plexus, 2009). More specifically, the song is a sympathetic appraisal of former US president [[Richard Nixon]] and mentions some of his positive achievements, inevitably overshadowed by the [[Watergate Scandal]]. The timing of the single's release, two weeks before [[George W. Bush]]'s victory at the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 US presidential elections]], can also be seen as a statement by the band concerning the reputation of the USA's leadership at the time.{{cite book |last=Power |first=Martin |title=Manic Street Preachers |date=17 October 2010 |publisher=Omnibus Press}} In an interview with Repeat Fanzine, the band also said it represents how they feel in comparison to [[Radiohead]]. Nicky in particular commented that they feel like [[Richard Nixon]] compared to Radiohead's [[John F. Kennedy]]: "'If Radiohead are Kennedy, then Manic Street Preachers are Nixon: the ugly duckling who had to try 10 times harder than anyone else. Paranoid megalomaniacs.'"{{cite web |url=http://www.repeatfanzine.co.uk/interviews/MSP%20with%20Simon%20Price.htm |title=An Interview |website=repeatfanzine.co.uk |accessdate=12 April 2015}} The sound is more [[electronic music|electronic]] than most of their previous hits, indicative of a slight switch in sound on ''Lifeblood''; according to the band the song contains no guitars. == Release == "The Love of Richard Nixon" was released on 18 October 2004 by record label Epic as the first single from the band's seventh studio album, ''Lifebood''. It hit number 2 in the [[UK Singles Chart|UK charts]].{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/20086/MANIC%20STREET%20PREACHERS/ |title=Manic Street Preachers|website=[[Official Charts Company|Official Charts]] |accessdate=12 April 2015}} == Track listing == ; CD single 1 # "The Love of Richard Nixon" – 3:38 # "Everyone Knows/Nobody Cares" – 4:12 ; CD single 2 # "The Love of Richard Nixon" – 3:38 # "Everything Will Be" – 5:08 # "Askew Road" – 2:58 # "The Love of Richard Nixon" (video) ; DVD # "The Love of Richard Nixon" (video) # ''Quarantine (In My Place Of)'' (short film) – 3:50 # "Voodoo Polaroids" – 3:55 == Charts == {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! {{news release|1=article|date=February 2018}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2007}} {{no footnotes|date=November 2013}} [[Image:Opera Vienna.jpg|thumb|160px|Viennese Opera Ball New York 2017 at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel ]] [[File:Viennese Opera Ball New York 2017 .jpg|thumb|Viennese Opera Ball New York 2017 at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel NY]] [[File:Viennese Opera Ball New York .jpg|thumb|VOBNY Logo]] The '''Viennese Opera Ball'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vienneseoperaball.com/|title=Viennese Opera Ball|website=Viennese Opera Ball|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> is an annual charity gala held annually under the auspices of the United States-Austrian Chamber of Commerce. The Ball is organized by Board of Directors, under President Silvia Frieser and Artistic Director [[Daniel Serafin]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vienneseoperaball.com/performers/|title=Entertainment at the 63rd Viennese Opera Ball|date=2016-12-15|work=Viennese Opera Ball|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://t2conline.com/viennese-opera-ball-kick-offs-with-a-champagne-celebration/|title=Viennese Opera Ball Kick-Offs with a Champagne Celebration {{!}} Times Square Chronicles|website=t2conline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref>
Dignitaries, Diplomats and Debutantes “Open” the international Ball, long regarded as one of [[New York City]]’s “greatest annual events,” garnering worldwide media coverage for over five decades. There is nothing formulaic about the event; with four generations of guests, the Ball reflects the universal appeal of Austria’s cultural and culinary treasures. The gala evening features Opera, Classical Music and Ballroom Dancing including, of course, Waltzing. One popular highlight is the Midnight Quadrille, conducted by a Viennese choreographer. Following an 8 p.m. champagne reception, the Ball runs from 9:00 p.m. to 1:00 a.m., and includes a four-course dinner service. The “Tanz Bar” (post-Ball party) follows from 1:00 to 4:00 a.m. and includes a full buffet supper with the Viennese Opera Ball's Signature Goulash Soup, as well as multiple venues featuring: live dance music, a DJ and a Vienna Coffee House with Viennese pastries.
The Ball opens with the Grand March of Dignitaries and Diplomats. The ceremonial tone of the Ball Opening continues with the Presentation and Posting of the Flags by a West Point Color Guard. The Program continues with the Presentation of [[Debutante]]s (ages 16 to 26) and their dance Escorts (ages 18–30). A choreographed [[waltz]] routine by young [[ballroom dance]] couples (ages 18–30) is followed by a call for "Alles Walzer!" (Everyone Dance!) and guests join the dancers for the first official waltz of the Ball. A Viennese Orchestra plays continuous dance music throughout the Ball, stopping only for Program highlights or performances by the featured Opera singers.
== History ==
The Viennese Opera Ball in New York takes its inspiration from the famous [[Vienna Opera Ball]] in [[Austria]], but it is an American [[501(c)(3)]] non-profit association, and independent from the Vienna Opera Ball. In February 2018 the ball celebrated its 63rd Anniversary.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://theknockturnal.com/63rd-annual-viennese-opera-ball-announces-new-ziegfeld-ballroom-location-at-champagne-reception/|title=63rd Annual Viennese Opera Ball Announces New Ziegfeld Ballroom Location at Champagne Reception - The Knockturnal|date=2017-11-13|work=The Knockturnal|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
The ball normally takes place on the first Friday in February at the Waldorf Astoria in [[Manhattan]]. In 2018 the ball was held at the [[Ziegfeld Ballroom]] as the Waldorf Astoria is closed for renovations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://theknockturnal.com/63rd-annual-viennese-opera-ball-announces-new-ziegfeld-ballroom-location-at-champagne-reception/|title=63rd Annual Viennese Opera Ball Announces New Ziegfeld Ballroom Location at Champagne Reception - The Knockturnal|date=2017-11-13|work=The Knockturnal|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref> It is considered one of the few 'white-tie' balls still in existence in the United States, i.e. the gentlemen come attired in [[white tie]] and [[dress coat]]s with [[wiktionary:Decoration|decoration]]s and the ladies wear long floor-length [[ball gown]]s with decorations and [[Evening gloves|opera gloves]].
== Performances ==
Debutantes and their male partners (called Escorts) rehearse for one week prior to the ball, and they are generally selected by recommendation from Committee members each year. The choreographed Waltzers rehearse for three months prior to the ball, and they are selected from dance auditions held by the Choreographer each year. Opera singers come from the [[Metropolitan Opera]], and ballet dancers are flown over from [[Vienna]]. The Debutante procession is typically led by either the reigning [[Miss USA]] or the reigning [[Miss Universe]].
== Annual Themes ==
Each year there is a different theme: 2005 -- 'Golden Jubilee' (in honor of the 50th anniversary of both the Ball and Free Austria); 2006 -- 'Mozart,' as the night of the ball fell on what would have been [[Mozart]]'s 250th birthday; 2007 -- "Cinderella", complete with a ballet following the story of [[Cinderella]] and her night at "the ball" with [[Prince Charming]]; 2008 -- "Fairy Doll", inspired by composer [[Josef Bayer]]'s children's tale; and, 2009 -- "Masked Night at the Opera", inspired by [[Strauss]]'s "Prince Orlofsky's masked ball at his "villa" in "Die Fledermaus". Most recently in 2018, the 63rd Viennese Opera Ball commemorated the 100th anniversary of [[Gustav Klimt]]'s legacy.
==See also== * [[Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner]] * [[Gridiron Club Dinner]] * [[International Debutante Ball]] * [[United States presidential inaugural balls]] * [[White House Correspondents' Association#White House Correspondents' Dinner|White House Correspondents' Dinner]]
